headlines: ["Announcement of BMM summer course 2025 timing and location", "BMM summer course requests self-introduction slide submission"]
anchors: ["MBL Woods Hole", "course start August 3rd", "Surname_GivenName", "self-introduction slide", "August 3rd deadline", "tentative schedule", "three weeks", "student introduction session", "summer course 2025", "google drive link"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Mengmi Zhang
To: yzhuan13@jh.edu
Time: 2025-07-19T18:28:57+08:00
Subject: Welcome to BMM summer course 2025
Dear Yan Zhuang,
Welcome to the BMM summer course 2025! It will be an exciting and busy
3 weeks packed with super fun activities and rich learning
experiences!
The course will be held in MBL, Woods Hole starting in about a
month (August 3rd, 2025)!
I am Mengmi.
Brian, Morgan (in cc) and I are the head TAs for the course.
Please do not hesitate to reach out to any of us if you have questions, need
assistance, or just want to chat. Together with other TAs and faculty
members, we are here to support you every step of the way.
=====
To get to know each other better, we ask you to create one brief
self-introduction slide. Please include your name, a picture of
yourself, research interests, hobbies, and anything fun about yourself
you'd like to share.
You can upload your introduction slide through the google drive link here:
https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1ycUlU3bxG9bGXcWAwfp92RtMks2WqK_F?usp=sharing
(name the presentation file as Surname_GivenName)
Please submit your slide by midnight, August 3rd. You will present
your slide during the student introduction session on August 4th
afternoon. The course schedule will be made available here (the
schedule might change; check regularly for updates):
https://cbmm.mit.edu/summer-school/2025
For your quick reference, I attached a tentative schedule:
https://drive.google.com/file/d/11lDvJQTZr2e0l3W5fG3z7t7ZZPzOTZbr/view?usp=sharing
======
Once again, welcome to the upcoming BMM Summer Course! We look forward
to meeting you in person in Woods Hole!
-- 
Best,
Mengmi
Nanyang assistant professor and PI of Deep NeuroCognition Lab
College of Computing and Data Science
Nanyang Technological University (NTU), Singapore
Lab website: https://a0091624.wixsite.com/deepneurocognition-1
Our lab: CIL@ N4-B1A-02; My office: N3-02c-89 @ NTU

headlines: ["Crisis24 itinerary created for upcoming UC business trip to Los Angeles"]
anchors: ["Los Angeles United States", "country rating 2 low", "record locator X23NNW", "city rating 2 low", "travel insurance coverage"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Crisis24 Horizon
To: GKREIMAN@GMAIL.COM
Time: 2025-04-23T17:43:53+00:00
Subject: UCLA: Security and travel insurance reminders for your upcoming
 trip
|  Complete these pre-travel safety steps to reduce your travel risk
---
GABRIEL A KREIMAN,
UC Travel Insurance coverage applies to UC employees and students while traveling on UC business. For details on the UC Travel Insurance coverage and benefits, visit the [UC Travel Risk and Insurance](https://www.ucop.edu/risk-services-travel/index.html) webpage.
Click here to learn more about [UC's partnership with Crisis24](https://www.ucop.edu/risk-services-travel/crisis24.html).
Crisis24 has received itinerary details for your upcoming trip:
Trip Details:
**Trip Name:** Not Provided
**Trip Start Date:** Wed, May 7, 2025 06:00 (GMT-04:00) / Wed, May 7, 2025 10:00 (UTC)
**Trip End Date:** Sat, May 10, 2025 07:26 (GMT-04:00) / Sat, May 10, 2025 11:26 (UTC)
**Record Locator:** X23NNW
To facilitate your safety while traveling please complete all 5 steps:
### **STEP 1:  CREATE A CRISIS24 HORIZON ACCOUNT**
Please click on the link below and complete required fields to activate your Crisis24 Horizon account. The link will expire after 48 hours. If the link has expired, please follow the instructions to complete your account activation. **Member ID: UCLACampus**
|  Create Account
---
### **STEP 2:  UPDATE YOUR CONTACT INFORMATION AND TRAVEL ALERT SETTINGS**
  * Complete your _Profile_  including emergency contact information.
  * Review/Edit setting options for receiving real-time alerts.
### **STEP 3:  DOWNLOAD THE CRISIS24 HORIZON MOBILE APP**
Search for “Crisis24 Horizon Mobile” from the [App store](https://apps.apple.com/bm/app/crisis24-horizon-mobile/id1593231160) or [Android Google Play](https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.crisis24.horizon&hl=en&pli=1) and download the app.
**_Sign In_**  to the Crisis24 Horizon Mobile App using your username and password from Step 1.
**Important Horizon Mobile App features:**
**Hotline Button:  **Use this button to connect with University of California's 24x7 Chubb-AXA Global Travel Assistance center in the event of an incident.
**Crisis Button:**  Use this button if you need immediate assistance during a dynamic security event and cannot speak on the phone. Defer to the hotline button if you can.
### **STEP 4: PRINT OR DOWNLOAD INSURANCE CARD**
In case of an emergency while traveling internationally, please contact Chubb-AXA Global Travel Assistance using your insurance contact card. _A link to this card can also be accessed under "Useful Links' in the Crisis24 Horizon mobile app.  _
For additional guidance about submitting claims see Claims Portal Guidelines.
### **STEP 5:  REVIEW YOUR TRIP BRIEF**
Access location intelligence related to your destination by clicking the Country Brief or City Brief link(s) below -or- by accessing it within the Crisis24 Horizon web app (link below) or mobile app. To add a Location in the mobile app click the symbol to the right of 'My Locations,' then click 'Add Saved Location.'
**Destinations:**
Access location briefs anytime by clicking on the “Horizon App” link below and login. Country and City Brief links are only accessible without login from the trip booking date and time through the trip end date and time.
**Los Angeles, United States**
| |  City Rating:
|  2 - Low
| |  Country Rating:
|  2 - Low

---|---|---

Notices: |
---|---
| | |  Data Protection:
If you are traveling with electronic devices, it is important to take steps to protect and secure information stored on those devices. Consider some of the following steps to protect your information:
  * Leave your data or laptop at home or use a loaner laptop wiped clean before your trip
  * Backup your data
  * Use a Virtual Private Network (VPN)
  * Password protect (secure) or encrypt (more secure) your hard drive
  * Maintain physical control of your devices at all times, or secure them in a locked desk or hotel safe to prevent theft or unauthorized access
  * Only connect trusted items to your devices (e.g. thumb drives or wireless devices)
Contact your local IT administrator for assistance if needed. For more information on IT security guidance, visit the Systemwide Information Security website.
**Hand carrying computers, research materials, samples or equipment** When you travel abroad, everything you take with you is an export including hand carried equipment, research materials, and unpublished or proprietary information or data. Your local Export Control Office can determine whether an export license is required to travel with these items.

headlines: ["Announcement of Joe Rosenbaum\u2019s passing and tribute link"]
anchors: ["AgeTech community", "passed away", "life of Joseph Howard Rosenbaum", "tribute message"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Jeff Gray
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-07-20T23:28:36+00:00
Subject: Sunday nights
Sunday nights 7/20
I’m on a plane home from a trip to Los Angeles that started with another spectacular meetup put on by Danniel Fuchs and culminated with a day that included three birthday celebrations — two of them for 90 year old friends!
Here’s what’s on my mind tonight.
Last weekend I was saddened to learn that Joe Rosenbaum passed away. He is the father of my dear friend Maurice Rosenbaum who is also one of the great leaders in our AgeTech community.
Maurice and I met through our fathers, John and Joe, who had signed up for Vivo virtual strength training classes. It was the middle of the pando and I had traveled to Boca Raton to help my daughter move from there back to Atlanta. I logged into the class from my hotel room and the four of us had a great workout together.
I didn’t get to know Joe well, but Maurice and I would become close friends and join forces to build a global community of innovators who redefining the experience of aging through technology.
The apple doesn’t fall far from the tree, so if you know Maurice you also know quite a bit about Joe, even if you've never met him. First and foremost, Maurice is the kindest person I know. His face always lights up with a warm smile when he meets you, and he always wants to know how you’re doing before talking business. He’s the kind of guy that will share the highs and lows with you.
In his role as the founder and CEO of Boncrest he is always eager to meet with AgeTech founders and tries his best to help them. He offers thoughtful advice, is always a cheerleader, and often tests or pilots new innovations. He’s never too busy to help.
Maurice is a wonderful husband and father. He’s always talking about his family and prioritizes them above all else. And he’s a true friend. Maurice is always there for you.
Joe, thank you for bringing Maurice and I together, and for raising a son who became such an exemplary man. The flame of your legacy burns brightly in him.
Jeff
Read about the life of Joseph Howard Rosenbaum here: 
==============================================
You are receiving this email because you are a members of the AgeTech Atlanta community or opted in via our website.
Our telephone:
4045502224

https://us11.forward-to-friend.com/forward?u=53adb10a42e57c428eca39254&id=46f19e7833&e=0eeb6c8ba8

Time: 2025-04-16T20:05:19-04:00
Subject: Data Room w/ documents outlining the business and tech of Memorious
Hi Debi,
Hope you're doing well! As promised on our last call, we’re sharing access
to our Data Room, which includes several documents detailing our strategy
at Memorious. This includes:
   -
   A revised pitch deck incorporating your past feedback
   -
   Market research report
   -
   Go-to-market strategy
   -
   Strategic roadmap
   -
   18-month P&L aligned with roadmap milestones
   -
   Technical report / white paper
   -
   -
   Privacy tech report detailing how privacy is built into our architecture
We’d really value your feedback on these—especially from the lens of a
seasoned investor—as we prepare for the fundraise. Please let us know what
resonates, what could be stronger, and how we can sharpen the materials.
Warm regards,
Spandan

Message 1

To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-11-04T09:41:20-05:00
Subject: Event reminder: R&D and QSBS: Unlocking Tax Advantages for Founders - 11/5
Hi Gabriel,
We look forward to seeing you tomorrow, Wednesday, November 5th, for *R&D
and QSBS: Unlocking Tax Advantages for Founders!*
In this session, we’ll explore with Citrin Cooperman how early-stage
investments in research and development (R&D) can result in cash tax
savings and a valuable tax asset —and how the Qualified Small Business
Stock (QSBS) exemption can provide substantial tax savings when it’s time
to exit.
See you tomorrow at 12:30pm ET via Zoom!
Best,
Jenni & the Underscore VC team

headlines: ["Harvard College Fund donation request for research support"]
anchors: ["Harvard College Fund", "stock and planned gifts", "critical research", "fiscal year close", "online donation page"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Dean Hopi Hoekstra"
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-06-30T08:30:52-06:00
Subject: Help Harvard meet this moment
View this email in your browser .
https://give.harvard.edu/campaigns/55596/donations/new?appeal_code=F25E25M2S&hide_appeal_code=1&utm_source=dbng&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=F25E25M2S&utm_content=bi_acu_2025-06-30&utm_term=m 
 Dear Mr. Kreiman,
In my role as Edgerley Family Dean of the Harvard Faculty of Arts and Sciences, I have been inspired—time and again—by the dedication and commitment of our parent and alumni community. I am calling on you today to help us meet this moment and sustain critical research. 
Research benefits all of us. Across the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, faculty and students are working in more than 170 research labs, focusing on areas ranging from health to climate to artificial intelligence. Scientific breakthroughs made at Harvard influence the way we treat disease and drive transformative technological innovations. We need your support today to ensure the discoveries of tomorrow.
https://give.harvard.edu/campaigns/55596/donations/new?appeal_code=F25E25M2S&hide_appeal_code=1&utm_source=dbng&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=F25E25M2S&utm_content=bi_acu_2025-06-30&utm_term=m 
Count Me In 
Please make a gift to the Harvard College Fund. Through your generosity, the Harvard College Fund can help us respond to urgent needs, support students and their research opportunities right away, and safeguard future advances that benefit the world. You can learn more about the Harvard research at risk on 
this webpage .
As our current fiscal year comes to a close today, your gift will help us meet the unknowns of the new academic year with both flexibility and resilience. I am grateful for your support and for the collective impact that every gift of every size has in these unprecedented times. Through the help of many, we are forging a path together.
Sincerely,
Hopi Hoekstra
Edgerley Family Dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences
C. Y. Chan Professor of Arts and Sciences
Xiaomeng Tong and Yu Chen Professor of Life Sciences
 Harvard University also welcomes gifts of 
stock, bank wires, matching gifts , and 
planned gifts . Gifts by mail or through donor-advised funds may be sent to: PO Box 55997 Boston, MA 02205-9727. For assistance or questions about your giving history, please contact Alumni and Development Services at 
mailto:ads@harvard.edu 
ads@harvard.edu  or 1-800-VERITAS. For all other questions, please write to 
mailto:hcf_pep@harvard.edu 
hcf_pep@harvard.edu .
 Please note that the current fiscal year at Harvard aligns with the academic year and runs from July 1, 2024, through June 30, 2025.
Harvard University | 124 Mount Auburn Street | Cambridge, MA 02138
Your HAA ID number is: 0005216315
Harvard respects your privacy. Please see our 
privacy statement  for more information.
Removal Instructions: If you no longer wish to receive appeal emails from Harvard College Parent Engagement Programs, please

anchors: ["identify what Phase", "what model will be needed", "Value column", "aspirational questions", "data collection channel"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Spandan Madan
To: Gabriel Kreiman
Time: 2025-03-26T16:56:06-04:00
Subject: Assigning value to Aspirational Questions
Hi Gabriel,
I went through all the Aspirational questions you had in the Google
sheets---very, very valuable. Thank you for putting in that effort of
coming up with those use cases.
For each, I concretely thought what it would take to answer it correctly.
For each, there are two parts---(1) Data collection channel (zoom,
in-person, email, etc.) and (2) What model will be needed to get the
answer. For each, I can confidently say what is to be done technologically.
This also gives me a sense of how difficult it will be.
Treating you as "User Zero", the most useful next step would be to identify
how valuable each of these would be, if you were a user. Can you fill out
the *Value* column in the "Gabriel's" sheet? Here's the link:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Y4PFHkuS3VDh7S77boWxeHkytJGP6FkIdsJPaJCyUY4/edit?gid=0#gid=0
.
We can then go over the Difficulty and Value columns to identify what
"Phase" each should be covered in. I suppose this is the most fun part of
working on Memorious :D
Best,
Spandan

headlines: ["NSF inquiry about CBMM supplement for partnerships workshop", "Poggio forwards NSF supplement opportunity asking for interest"]
anchors: ["non-academic partnerships", "no-cost extension", "award supplement", "anybody interested", "forwarded message", "partnerships workshop"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Tomaso Poggio
To:
  - James DiCarlo
  - Kathleen D Sullivan
  - Josh Tenenbaum
  - Gabriel Kreiman
  - Boris Katz
  - Matthew A Wilson
  - Nancy Kanwisher
Time: 2025-08-15T14:33:05-04:00
Subject: Fwd: interest in CBMM award supplement for partnerships workshop?
Anybody interested?
tommy
-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: 	interest in CBMM award supplement for partnerships workshop?
Date: 	Fri, 15 Aug 2025 18:21:32 +0000
From: 	Morss, Rebecca E. 
To: 	Tommy Poggio: , Jim DiCarlo: , 
Josh Tenebaum: 
Hi,
Dragana Brzakovic retired in March, and I am now managing the NSF STC 
program. The program is interested funding a supplement to one of the 
STCs to design and implement a workshop on Center non-academic 
partnerships, with an emphasis on industry and foundations and other 
non-profits. The general goal would be to discuss different STCs’ and 
partners’ perspectives and experiences, in order to share knowledge 
among the STCs (especially for the newer STCs) and with the STC program. 
Given CBMM’s experience with these types of partnerships, we thought the 
Center would be well-suited for this effort.
Phil Regalia said that CBMM is on a no-cost extension that ends on Aug 
31, and so the timeline on moving forward is short. Please let me know 
whether you and/or others at CBMM are potentially interested. If so, I 
can answer any questions and we can set up a time for a quick 
conversation. And if not, thank you for considering this, and we’ll 
reach out to another Center.
Best,
Rebecca
Rebecca E. Morss, PhD
Program Director, Science and Technology Centers: Integrative 
Partnerships 
& Growing Convergence Research 
programs
Office of Integrative Activities
U.S. National Science Foundation

headlines: ["IIAS opens 2027-2028 Individual Fellowships and Research Groups applications"]
people: ["Israel Institute for Advanced Studies <iias@mail.huji.ac.il>", "Prof. Yitzhak Hen"]
anchors: ["Research Groups", "Individual Fellowships", "residency options", "application deadline December 1, 2025", "application system open"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Israel Institute for Advanced Studies
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-09-07T06:55:31-07:00
Subject: IIAS Individual Fellowships & Research Groups (2027-2028):
 Applications Now Open
Dear friends of the IIAS,
*We are pleased to let you know that the application system for the 2027**-2028
Individual Fellowships and Research Groups at the Israel Institute for
Advanced Studies is now open.*
*We would be **extremely grateful if you could help us spread the word by
sharing this call within your academic networks.*
As you may know, *the IIAS offers two flagship programs:*
   - *Individual Fellowships: for tenured scholars seeking an inspiring
   environment to pursue innovative research in any discipline.*
   - *Research Groups: for teams of 5**-**8 tenured scholars to collaborate
   on interdisciplinary projects.*
*Residency Options: 10 months, 5 months, or 3 months* (for experimental
sciences groups). Fellows and Research Groups will conduct their research
at the IIAS on the Edmond J. Safra Campus, *at the Hebrew University of
Jerusalem.** Attached are the Open Calls for Individual Fellowships and
Research Groups*, as well as a short brochure about the Institute.
Application deadline: December 1, 2025
*Further details are available here: IIAS Open Calls
*
With warm regards and many thanks for your assistance,
Saul
*On behalf of Prof. Yitzhak Hen, Head of the IIAS*
-- 
*Saul Shargorodsky** | *Marketing and Digital Media Coordinator
*Israel Institute for Advanced Studies*
The Hebrew University of Jerusalem
T +972.2.6584493 | +97.2.548014329

Subject: Reminder: March 12 Milestone Meeting
Hi founders,
Just a reminder that we have a Milestone Meeting coming up March 12th. This is a required meeting for all teams. As some of you remember from last time, you will have a timeslot, so you don’t need to be there for the whole 2 hours. Each team will have 15 mins. to go through their milestones and provide an update to the Board.
I will send out a form to fill out about your company update that serves as a pre-read for the Board so that they can come to the meeting prepared to make the most of the time they have with you. Keep an eye out for this and please complete it in a timely manner so I can get it to the Board a few days before we meet.
Hope everyone is having a great week!
Best
DK
Debi Kleiman | The AI Lab for Startups | Digital Data Design Institute at Harvard  | HARVARD BUSINESS SCHOOL

headlines: ["Science Advances rejects manuscript adw9202 and Haim requests missing reviews"]
topics: ["Unraveling the Geometry of Visual Relational Reasoning"]
anchors: ["resend the reviews", "manuscript rejection", "missing attachment", "detailed reviews"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Haim Sompolinsky
To: scienceadvanceseditorial@aaas.org
Time: 2025-03-02T10:55:57-05:00
Subject: Re: Decision on Science Advances manuscript adw9202
Dear Editor,
Your email below says that you have received detailed reviews of our manuscript and indicates they were attached to the email.
However, no document has been attached.
Can you resend the reviews?
Thanks in advance,
Best regards,
Haim
> On Mar 1, 2025, at 9:22 PM, Science Advances Editorial  wrote:
> 
>  
> Ref: Ms. No. adw9202
> Title: Unraveling the Geometry of Visual Relational Reasoning
> 
> Dear Dr. Sompolinsky,
> 
> Thank you for submitting your manuscript to Science Advances.
> 
> We have now received detailed reviews of your manuscript (see attached). Unfortunately, the reviewer comments are not positive enough to support publication of the paper in Science Advances. Although we recognize that you might be able address many of the criticisms noted in the reviews, the overall nature of the comments is such that we believe that the manuscript would not make the final cut for publication. We are therefore letting you know that we are rejecting the manuscript and hope that, nonetheless, you find the review comments helpful in preparing your work for submission to another journal.
> 
> Science Advances receives many very interesting submissions, more than we can possibly send out for in-depth review or publish. Our decision regarding your manuscript is therefore not necessarily a reflection of the quality of your work, but rather of our constraints and goals in publishing high impact results across a broad and balanced array of disciplines.
> 
> We are sorry that we could not be more positive on this occasion, but we appreciate the opportunity to consider your manuscript. We wish you success in seeking publication in a journal better suited to your work.
> 
> Best Regards,
> 
> Tali Sharot, PhD
> Deputy Editor
> On behalf of the
> Science Advances Editorial Team
> 
> ===============================
>  
>  
> Need help? Please contact us at scienceadvanceseditorial@aaas.org 
> Information for Authors  | Information for Reviewers 
> 
> American Association for the Advancement of Science
> 1200 New York Avenue, NW
> Washington, DC 20005, USA
>  
> © 2025 AAAS

headlines: ["Bourbon tasting, dinner, and fireside chat at Angel's Envy Distillery", "Fireside chat on vendor selection with leaders from Sage and Discovery Senior Living", "Fourth Senior Living and Post-Acute Care Innovation Summit held in St. Petersburg", "Neelam Brar engages with Humana executive during fireside chat Q&A", "PrudentialPeak AgeTech Challenge Pitch competition co-presented in Louisville"]
topics: ["Senior Living and Post-Acute Care Innovation Summit", "PrudentialPeak AgeTech Challenge Pitch competition"]
people: ["Jeff | AgeTech Connect <jeff@agetechatlanta.com>", "Lindsey Daugherty", "Char Hu", "Missy Caple", "Esmerelda Lee", "Neelam Brar"]
anchors: ["technology as the central theme", "intriguing question", "vendor selection", "cocktail hour", "PrudentialPeak", "contest winner", "Thrive Center", "panel discussions", "keynotes", "senior living operator", "fireside chat", "Angel's Envy Distillery", "audience questions", "AgeTech founder", "Total Life", "Q&A", "questions from audience", "invitation-only event", "AgeTech Challenge Pitch", "bourbon tasting", "fireside chats", "follow-up conversation", "Medicare Product Development", "startup founders"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Jeff | AgeTech Connect
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-10-12T22:59:44+00:00
Subject: Sunday night insights...
I hope you're enjoying a great long weekend. You're receiving this "almost every Sunday night" email because you are a friend, stakeholder, or supporter of the AgeTech Connect movement. If you'd prefer not to receive future installments, send me a note and I'll remove you from the list.
Here's what is on my mind tonight.
A week ago, I hosted our fourth Senior Living and Post-Acute Care Innovation Summit in St. Petersburg, Florida. Leading executives in senior living and post-acute care attended this invitation-only event, along with researchers and educators from USF St. Pete. We always invite a small group of technology vendors to participate in an innovation showcase, so there were about 12 AgeTech startup founders there as well.
The program for the day's learning journey included keynotes, fireside chats, and panel discussions on a variety of topics, with technology as the central theme. One of the fireside chats was a conversation led by Lindsey Daugherty, Head of Community at Sage, and Esmerelda Lee, SVP of Operations at Discovery Senior Living. Discovery is now the second-largest senior living operator in the United States, with nearly four hundred communities.
Esmerelda shared valuable insights on many topics, and I found her commentary on how Discovery has looked at vendor selection particularly interesting. Near the end of the session, Esmerelda agreed to field some questions from the audience, and I expected every startup founder to jump at the chance to engage with Esmerelda and ask a question. Much to my surprise, no one other than me raised a hand to ask a question. I was stunned to see these founders let a priceless opportunity like this slip away.
Rewind to a few weeks earlier. I had travelled to Louisville, where I co-presented the PrudentialPeak AgeTech Challenge Pitch competition at the new Thrive Center. Total Life, led by founder and CEO Neelam Brar, won the contest. Neelam is one of my favorite founders. She's smart, a fierce competitor, and works as hard as anyone I've ever met. And Total Life is a great success story in the making.
After the pitch competition, our hosts treated us to a bourbon tasting and dinner at Angel's Envy Distillery. Between the cocktail hour and dinner, we listenend to a fireside chat with Char Hu, founder and CEO of the Helper Bees, and Missy Caple, Vice President, Medicare Product Development at Humana. At the end - you guessed it - Missy agreed to take a few questions. Neelam's hand immediately shot up, and she asked an intriguing question, which led to a follow-up conversation later in the evening.
Neelam was focused, prepared, and she seized the opportunity.
Founders, especially those struggling to find product-market fit, should be prepared to take advantage of an unplanned encounter with an A-list executive who can change the trajectory of their venture. They should always show up ready to ask a good question, and never let a chance to connect with an industry mogul slip away.
Seize every opportunity, because you never know when you'll get another one.
Jeff
PS - Shout out to the sponsors who made these two events possible: Prudential, Amba, Inspiren, Sage, The Thrive Center, CDW, OneStep, Faegre Drinker, Milliman
==============================================

headlines: ["Transition of AI Lab for Startups program mission to IQSS"]
anchors: ["programmatic mission", "smooth transition", "research mission", "no interruption", "university-wide academic entrepreneurship program"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Stave, Jennifer"
To:
  - klakhani@g.harvard.edu
  - king@harvard.edu
  - Jackson, Elizabeth
Time: 2025-03-21T16:08:36+00:00
Subject: AI Lab for Startups transition
Dear AI Lab for Startup community,
We write today with an exciting update on the AI Lab for Startups, formerly known as the Startup Foundry at D^3. The successful launch of this program has been a thrilling journey filled with important lessons in bolstering entrepreneurship in academic settings - our initial cohort of founders, mentors, and board members were absolutely critical to the success.  As we move forward with growing the broader D^3 research institute, we have a heightened focus on our core competency of producing academically rigorous research.  We have decided to lean into these skills and increase our efforts on researching how AI is reshaping the entrepreneurial journey among global startups, providing the world with a better understanding of AI's role in scaling, strategy, and innovation.
In parallel, the  Institute for Quantitative Social Science (IQSS) has been working on launching a social science commercialization initiative. IQSS believes that there's an opportunity to advance the social sciences through commercialization and startup creation, both for the purpose of amplifying the scholarly work of the social sciences and to empower this scholarship with access to new data, people, platforms, knowledge, and other resources. IQSS is uniquely suited to tap into new innovations in the quantitative social sciences to use these developments to commercialize existing work and to simultaneously advance the goals of social science faculty, postdocs, and students across the University.
HBS and IQSS have collaborated closely since the early days of D^3 and the Foundry. IQSS was instrumental to the original incubation and ultimately founding of D^3, and has been involved throughout the whole history of the Startup Foundry. IQSS has been participating in the ongoing Advisory Board and together we created a resource sharing partnership to offer founders fractional Chief Product Officer consulting through IQSS. Earlier this year, IQSS began scoping and exploring a co-branded, formal sponsorship of the AI Lab for Startups to recognize and expand the collaboration. We are excited to tell you that we are all aligned on IQSS as the new home for the AI Lab for Startups programmatic mission, while D^3 focuses on its research mission.
We appreciate the common interest throughout our community in this move to IQSS from all stakeholders, including our donors, the leadership of D^3, IQSS, HBS, FAS, and the whole university.  We look forward to building on the success and momentum we have seen over the last two years and hope to take this to the next level. We plan to elevate the AI Lab for Startups to a university-wide academic entrepreneurship program, and to bring the work of startup formation closer to the academic/research community that is generating the technology, ideas, and new founders. Additionally, it will enable connecting with IQSS' broader industry-academic partnership goals for the benefit of social science research through incentive compatible collaboration. IQSS looks forward to continuing to foster the progress of the AI Lab for Startups and its goals, working with the stellar founders, researchers, and partners who have been part of this journey so far.
This transition will be effective as of Monday, March 24th. We anticipate a smooth transition with no interruption to the program. We (Gary and Elizabeth) look forward to engaging with you in the coming weeks in our redesign of the expanded program.
We are very grateful to this program's committed, enthusiastic and generous donor and the establishment of the "Kelly and Carla Kimball Fund for Entrepreneurship at the Faculty of Arts and Sciences". We also would like to thank Debi Kleiman for her ongoing leadership and stewardship of the program.
Best regards,
Jen Stave, Launch Director, Digital Data Design (D^3) Institute
Karim Lakhani, Dorothy & Michael Hintze Professor of Business Administration and Chair, D^3 Institute
Gary King, Albert J. Weatherhead III University Professor - Director, IQSS
Elizabeth Jackson, Executive Director, IQSS

headlines: ["Announcement of QED seminar on chemosensory tongue-flicking in snakes"]
anchors: ["chemosensory tongue-flicking", "Soft Math Lab", "Quantitative Ecology/Ethology/Evolution", "Zoom registration"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Perlo, Barbara L."
To: Perlo, Barbara L.
Time: 2025-11-06T22:39:40+00:00
Subject: Quantitative Ecology/Ethology/Evolution Discussion - Nov. 13th
Quantitative Ecology/Ethology/Evolution Discussion - Nov. 13th
--------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Liu, Lucy >
Date: Thu, Nov 6, 2025 at 1:02 PM
Subject: QED Seminar - Smelling With Your Tongue - Prof. Kurt Schwenk - Thursday, Nov 13, at 3pm
To: Quantitative Eco/Evo/Etho Discussions >
Cc: Lakshminarayanan Mahadevan >, Golnar Gharooni Fard >
Please join us for a Quantitative Ecology/Ethology/Evolution Discussion!
Zoom registration and Web listing
[qed_kurt_schwenk.png]
Title: Smelling with your tongue: the biomechanics of chemosensory tongue-flicking in snakes
Time: Thursday, November 13 at 3pm ET
Speaker: Prof. Kurt Schwenk, Dept. of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, University of Connecticut
Abstract: In squamate reptiles (lizards and snakes), the tongue participates in two principal roles—feeding and chemoreception. Phenotypic optimization for one role is in opposition to optimization for the other. Consequently, most lineages manifest compromise phenotypes that function adequately in both roles. However, snake tongues have abandoned feeding function completely and become specialized for collecting volatile odor molecules from the air. Chameleon tongues, in contrast, have virtually lost chemosensory function and become specialized projectile organs capable of grasping prey with an intrinsically mobile tongue tip. I focus on the former, touching on the latter if there is time. We have known for a century that tongue-flicking (TF) in squamates collects environmental chemicals (odorants) and delivers them to tiny openings in the palate leading to paired vomeronasal organs, a secondary olfactory sense distinct from nasal olfaction. Lizard TFs consist of a single, protraction-up-down-retraction cycle with the tongue tips nearly always contacting the substrate. Snake tongue-flicks, in contrast, consist of multiple, sequential, high velocity tongue cycles (oscillatory tongue-flicking/OTF), many of which are aerial. Nevertheless, our understanding of the functional significance for TF in both is the same. Particle image velocimetry (PIV) of airflow around the tongue tips during OTF in garter snakes revealed that snakes generate two pairs of standing, counter-rotating, vortices that draw fresh air in from the sides, accelerating it vertically into the paths of the moving tongue tips. We hypothesize that rapid OTF and the organized advection system it creates serve to mitigate diffusive constraints on the rate of molecular mass transfer onto the tongue tips by means of boundary layer reduction and maintenance of a concentration gradient. It is also likely that OTF serves to integrate the chemical signal in patchy odor plumes temporally and spatially on each tine of the forked tongue, possibly providing directional information.
[image.png][image.png]
Bio: Kurt Schwenk is a functional morphologist and evolutionary biologist in the Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology at the University of Connecticut. He received a BA from Oberlin College in 1977 and then worked as a zookeeper at the Bronx Zoo in New York City before completing his Ph.D. at the University of California, Berkeley, in 1984. Dr. Schwenk’s research focuses on the anatomy, function, biomechanics, and evolution of feeding and chemosensory systems in terrestrial vertebrates, especially lizards and snakes. He uses his empirical work to address broader questions about phenotypic evolution, with a particular interest in the concept of evolutionary constraint. His work relies on the integration of data from gross anatomy, histology, photography, and high-speed macro-videography.
Hosted by the Soft Math Lab. For any questions, please contact Lucy Liu at lliu@g.harvard.edu.
CBS mailing list:
CBS@lists.fas.harvard.edu
https://lists.fas.harvard.edu/mailman/listinfo/cbs
For information on upcoming events, see: https://cbs.fas.harvard.edu/home/events/
Barbara Perlo
Events Coordinator, Center for Brain Science at Harvard University
bperlo@fas.harvard.edu
617-495-9765

headlines: ["Request to collaborate on AI-based dog vocalization study and facility recordings"]
topics: ["dog vocalizations in naturalistic settings using AI"]
anchors: ["on-site visit", "dog vocalizations", "research grant", "visual and audio recordings", "non-intrusive welfare-friendly"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Zhang Mengmi (Asst Prof)"
To: hello@pawsh.club
Time: 2025-09-11T05:57:32+00:00
Subject: Research Collaboration on Dog Vocalization Study
Dear Pawsh Club Team,
My name is Mengmi Zhang, Assistant Professor in College of Computing and Data Science at NTU. Our team plans to study dog vocalizations in naturalistic settings using Artificial Intelligence (AI), collecting visual and audio recordings to better understand how dogs communicate.
We are planning to apply for a research grant next year (e.g., AI for Science / CRP) to support this work and are very interested in a research collaboration with you. We would love to arrange a short meeting and on-site visit to discuss whether it’s possible to collect recordings at your facility in a non-intrusive, welfare-friendly way.
We would acknowledge your support in publications and share research insights that may benefit your work with dogs.
Please let us know if you are open to research collaborations. Thank you for your time, and we look forward to your reply.
Best,
Mengmi
Nanyang assistant professor and PI of Deep NeuroCognition Lab
College of Computing and Data Science
Nanyang Technological University
Lab website: https://a0091624.wixsite.com/deepneurocognition-1
CONFIDENTIALITY: This email is intended solely for the person(s) named and may be confidential and/or privileged. If you are not the intended recipient, please delete it, notify us and do not copy, use, or disclose its contents.
Towards a sustainable earth: Print only when necessary. Thank you.

headlines: ["Mengmi clarifies compensation and logistics for BMM TA position", "TA position offer for BMM summer school 2025", "Yehonatan requests technical details about BMM TA position"]
anchors: ["tutorials and lectures", "in-person TA meetings", "check in and check out dates", "course preparation", "TA position", "logistics details", "housing travel and meal expenses", "no salary", "summer school", "travel arrangements", "technical details", "housing during the course", "online Zoom meeting", "salary", "registration email"]
full_content:

  - Yehonatan Avidan
  - Andrei Barbu
  - Boris Katz
  - Gabriel Kreiman
Time: 2025-03-18T20:12:21+08:00
Subject: Re: TA Application for BMM - Yehonatan Avidan
Hi Yehonatan,
There is no salary for the TA position.
MBL will cover housing, travel, and meal expenses. Please reach out to MBL
directly for further details.
As the summer course approaches, there will likely be an online Zoom
meeting, since the TAs are located across different parts of the world.
Andrei will likely arrange in-person TA meetings in Boston before the
course begins. He will notify you if such a gathering takes place this year.
Looking forward to working with you!
On Tue, Mar 18, 2025 at 4:14 AM Yehonatan Avidan 
wrote:
> Hi Mengmi,
>
> Thank you very much for the opportunity — I’m excited to join the BMM
> course staff and look forward to the summer school.
>
> I would appreciate it if you could share some technical details regarding
> the position, such as information about salary, travel arrangements,
> housing during the course, etc.
>
> I’m happy to be involved in upcoming discussions about course preparation.
> I’ll also be attending Cosyne in person and will be at Harvard afterward,
> so I’m available for in-person meetings as well.
>
> I’ll keep an eye out for the registration email from MBL.
>
> Thanks again,
>
> Best regards,
> Yehonatan
>
>

> 24th, 2025.
>

>
> We will have a meeting later this term to discuss tutorials, lectures, and
> answer any questions.
>
> In the coming weeks after you confirm, please be on the lookout for an
> email from MBL. They will send a registration email. It's critical that you
> fill it out promptly when it arrives. Note that the dates you will use for
> that email are the check in and check out dates.

headlines: ["Thomas Serre announces limited availability during sabbatical and provides contact instructions"]
anchors: ["urgent matters text message", "prospective graduate students applications", "grant-related matters contact", "CCV-related matters subject line", "on sabbatical until September 1, 2025"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Serre, Thomas"
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-05-03T18:47:59-07:00
Subject: Out of Office: On Sabbatical Until September 1, 2025 Re: ONR Topic 14: Evaluation and Monitoring of Large-Scale Generative AI.
Hello,
Thank you for your email. I am currently on sabbatical until September 1, 2025, and will be largely unavailable during this period.
  * **Urgent matters** : Please send me a text message on my cell.
  * **CCV-related matters** : Please resend your email with "CCV" included in the subject line.
  * **Grant-related matters** : Please reach out to CLPSgrants@Brown.edu.
  * **Prospective graduate students:** I will be accepting graduate students. I recommend you apply to the graduate program in Cognitive Science or Computer Science. You may also apply to the graduate program in Neuroscience.
  * For all other inquiries, please resend your email after September 1, 2025, and I will respond as soon as possible upon my return.
Thank you for your understanding.
Best regards,
Thomas
--
--Thomas Serre
Brown University | Carney Institute for Brain Science
Thomas J. Watson, Sr. Professor of Science
Departments of Cognitive & Psychological Sciences and Computer Science
Faculty Director, Center for Computation & Visualization
Associate Director, Center for Computational Brain Science
ANR-3IA Artificial and Natural Intelligence Toulouse Institute
T: +1 401-863-1148 | [serre-lab.clps.brown.edu
](http://serre-lab.clps.brown.edu)

From: Nancy Koppelman
Sent: Monday, February 24, 2025 5:12 PM
To: James Russell; Poznansky, Mark C.,MD, PhD
Cc: Sarah Livingston; yag@gonch.name; davigan@bidmc.harvard.edu; lahav.galit@gmail.com; mhoutchens@bhw.harvard.edu; dan_shoag@hks.harvard.edu; jfried@law.harvard.edu; gilbert@wjh.harvard.edu; dstern@fas.harvard.edu; Kreiman, Gabriel; carol.ehrlich@gmail.com; dotan_greenvald@fas.harvard.edu; wisse@fas.harvard.edu; miribhalpern@gmail.com; gblum@law.harvard.edu; jlevenson@hds.harvard.edu; rebar@channing.harvard.edu; pinker@wjh.harvard.edu; stuart_schreiber@harvard.edu; steve_kelman@hks.harvard.edu; jhamburg@fas.harvard.edu; bargill@law.harvard.edu; eleekes@gmail.com; Sadie Weintraub
Subject: Re: AEN is coming to Harvard [EXTERNAL]
* External Email - Caution *
Greetings everyone – – thanks for your patience. The event tomorrow is from noon to 130 in the science and engineering complex, room 2.122. There will be box lunches at 11:30. Thank you so much for your interest in coming – – it will be a big help.
Nancy

From: Nancy Koppelman
Sent: Thursday, January 30, 2025 3:11:37 PM
To: James Russell ; Poznansky, Mark C.,MD, PhD
Cc: Sarah Livingston ; yag@gonch.name ; davigan@bidmc.harvard.edu ; lahav.galit@gmail.com ; mhoutchens@bhw.harvard.edu ; dan_shoag@hks.harvard.edu ; jfried@law.harvard.edu ; gilbert@wjh.harvard.edu ; dstern@fas.harvard.edu ; gabriel.kreiman@childrens.harvard.edu ; carol.ehrlich@gmail.com ; dotan_greenvald@fas.harvard.edu ; wisse@fas.harvard.edu ; miribhalpern@gmail.com ; gblum@law.harvard.edu ; jlevenson@hds.harvard.edu ; rebar@channing.harvard.edu ; pinker@wjh.harvard.edu ; stuart_schreiber@harvard.edu ; steve_kelman@hks.harvard.edu ; jhamburg@fas.harvard.edu ; bargill@law.harvard.edu ; eleekes@gmail.com ; Sadie Weintraub
Subject: Re: AEN is coming to Harvard
Greetings everyone,
Thanks, Mark, for asking about what kind of support is needed.  My sense from the SEAS staff is that my presentation will be better received if there are one or two people in the audience who are also affiliated with the AEN.  I have been keeping abreast of what's going on at Harvard, and my talk is definitely a step in the right direction.  If any of you are able to join me, I would be most grateful, and my hosts will have all the more reason to suggest bringing the AEN to speak at other schools on campus.  Please contact me directly if you are able to connect with me, and thanks so much.
Nancy
Nancy Koppelman
The Evergreen State College
Faculty Consultant for Special Projects
Academic Engagement Network

From: James Russell
Sent: Thursday, January 30, 2025 10:52 AM
To: Poznansky, Mark C.,MD, PhD
Cc: Sarah Livingston ; Nancy Koppelman ; yag@gonch.name ; davigan@bidmc.harvard.edu ; lahav.galit@gmail.com ; mhoutchens@bhw.harvard.edu ; dan_shoag@hks.harvard.edu ; jfried@law.harvard.edu ; gilbert@wjh.harvard.edu ; dstern@fas.harvard.edu ; gabriel.kreiman@childrens.harvard.edu ; carol.ehrlich@gmail.com ; dotan_greenvald@fas.harvard.edu ; wisse@fas.harvard.edu ; miribhalpern@gmail.com ; gblum@law.harvard.edu ; jlevenson@hds.harvard.edu ; rebar@channing.harvard.edu ; pinker@wjh.harvard.edu ; stuart_schreiber@harvard.edu ; steve_kelman@hks.harvard.edu ; jhamburg@fas.harvard.edu ; bargill@law.harvard.edu ; eleekes@gmail.com ; Sadie Weintraub
Subject: Re: AEN is coming to Harvard
Greetings and an early Good Shabbos, friends!
I'm emeritus and living nearly 3000 miles from campus, but am very glad some
people are fighting against the antisemitism that poisons Harvard and most of
the rest of American academia.
Be well and God bless,
James (Yakov)
James R. Russell
Mashtots Professor of Armenian Studies, Emeritus
Harvard University

Unfortunately I will be out of town that day – what precise help do you need. I could definitely speak to Nancy before the meeting if needed and apply a admin person from my team to help get RSVPs.
Best,
Mark
From: Sarah Livingston >
Sent: Thursday, January 30, 2025 9:54 AM
To: Nancy Koppelman >
Cc: yag@gonch.name; davigan@bidmc.harvard.edu; Poznansky, Mark C.,MD, PhD >; lahav.galit@gmail.com; mhoutchens@bhw.harvard.edu; dan_shoag@hks.harvard.edu; jfried@law.harvard.edu; gilbert@wjh.harvard.edu; dstern@fas.harvard.edu; gabriel.kreiman@childrens.harvard.edu; carol.ehrlich@gmail.com; dotan_greenvald@fas.harvard.edu; wisse@fas.harvard.edu; miribhalpern@gmail.com; gblum@law.harvard.edu; jlevenson@hds.harvard.edu; rebar@channing.harvard.edu; pinker@wjh.harvard.edu; stuart_schreiber@harvard.edu; steve_kelman@hks.harvard.edu; jhamburg@fas.harvard.edu; bargill@law.harvard.edu; russelldeep@gmail.com; eleekes@gmail.com; Sadie Weintraub >
Subject: AEN is coming to Harvard
        External Email - Use Caution
Dear Harvard AEN faculty members,
I have a request for support. An opportunity to show up for AEN and our mission to fight antisemitism on Harvard’s campus. Next month our Administrator Engagement consultant, Dr. Nancy Koppelman, is leading a session for the Harvard School of Engineering and Applied Sciences “Jewish Identity and Antisemitism on Campus.” This program is on 2/25, we are still confirming the time but we think it’s 1:00-3:00.
Nancy’s hosts at Harvard SEAS have explicitly told us that they want AEN members to attend the program. I would like to secure a volunteer to speak with Nancy ahead of the program and to get RSVPs from whomever is available to attend.
Please be in touch as soon as you can.
Thank you so much!
Sarah
Sarah Livingston, MA
Director of Member Engagement
Academic Engagement Network
Cell: (614) 440-4860
Email: sarah@academicengagement.org
Schedule a call with me on Calendly!
Connect with me:
LinkedIn  |  Facebook  |  Instagram

headlines: ["Automatic reply indicating sabbatical and interim contact instructions"]
anchors: ["urgent matters via text message", "grant-related matters contact", "CCV in subject line", "prospective graduate students programs", "on sabbatical until September 1, 2025"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Serre, Thomas"
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-05-22T07:36:53-07:00
Subject: Out of Office: On Sabbatical Until September 1, 2025 Re: meeting
Hello,
Thank you for your email. I am currently on sabbatical until September 1, 2025, and will be largely unavailable during this period.
  * **Urgent matters** : Please send me a text message on my cell.
  * **CCV-related matters** : Please resend your email with "CCV" included in the subject line.
  * **Grant-related matters** : Please reach out to CLPSgrants@Brown.edu.
  * **Prospective graduate students:** I will be accepting graduate students. I recommend you apply to the graduate program in Cognitive Science or Computer Science. You may also apply to the graduate program in Neuroscience.
  * For all other inquiries, please resend your email after September 1, 2025, and I will respond as soon as possible upon my return.
Thank you for your understanding.
Best regards,
Thomas
--
--Thomas Serre
Brown University | Carney Institute for Brain Science
Thomas J. Watson, Sr. Professor of Science
Departments of Cognitive & Psychological Sciences and Computer Science
Faculty Director, Center for Computation & Visualization
Associate Director, Center for Computational Brain Science
ANR-3IA Artificial and Natural Intelligence Toulouse Institute
T: +1 401-863-1148 | [serre-lab.clps.brown.edu
](http://serre-lab.clps.brown.edu)

residual stream as a dynamical system. Jesseba and I have done a bit more

any time and are interested, we'd love to hear your thoughts on this.
All the best,
Greg

Time: 2025-11-06T17:57:03+00:00
Subject: Your 1:1 meeting with Zhaoping Li on Mon 10 Nov
Thank you for signing up to meet with Zhaoping during her visit this coming Monday. Please check the information below and let me know if you need to make any changes.
Zhaoping Li
Monday 10 November
11:00
Gabriel Kreiman (NW 169)
NOON Seminar
Seminar (NW 425) introduced by Kenny Blum
1:30
Aravi Samuel (NW 257)
2:15
Lunch
3:30
SueYeon Chung (NW 195.05)
4:15
Venki Murthy (Biolabs 4027)
Title: Formulating and understanding vision: progress in theory and experiments
Abstract: Using our own brains to study our brains is extraordinary. In vision --- the dominant primate sense --- this makes us blind to our own blindness, leading us astray in asking theoretical questions. Centuries of work, including contributions from Kepler through Newton to Maxwell, laid foundation for understanding retina, mainly as an optical sampling device of the environment. Then, within just a decade (1950s - 60s), electrophysiological recordings leapt from retinal neurons to those in primary visual cortex (V1), revealing how optical signals are transformed to signals in individual neurons. Yet progress beyond V1 has been markedly slower than the leap from retina to V1.
What, then, is vision as it advances from retina to mind?   A suitable formulation must recognize the brain's information processing (attentional) bottleneck, which admits a tiny fraction of retinal visual input for deeper processing. A fresh formulation (Zhaoping 2014, 2019) posits vision as looking and seeing: looking --- mainly by shifting gaze --- selects information for entry into the bottleneck, while seeing recognizes or infers object properties from what is selected. Since we are blind to non-selected inputs, understanding looking --- which often occurs before and even without seeing --- is essential to understanding vision as a whole.
This formulation generates falsifiable predictions, tested experimentally in psychology and neuroscience. Discoveries include a functional role of V1 in exogenously guiding gaze shifts, the involvement of neural circuits within and beyond V1, and new visual illusions in the process of seeing (Zhaoping 2025). These advances yield uncanny insights into our vision and mind. This framework can be extended to understand senses and minds of other animal species, e.g.,  rodents, fish, birds, bats, insects, many dominantly use a non-visual sense to "see" their world (Zhaoping 2023).
References:
Zhaoping, L. (2014) Understanding vision: theory, models, and data, Oxford University Press.
Zhaoping, L. (2019) A new framework for understanding vision from the perspective of the primary visual cortex. Current Opinion in Neurobiology, volume 58, page 1-10.
Zhaoping, L. (2023) Peripheral and central sensation: Multisensory orienting and recognition across species, Trends for Cognitive Sciences, Vol 27, issue 6, page 539-552.
Zhaoping, L. (2025) Testing the top-down feedback in the central visual field using the reversed depth illusion, iScience, Volume 28, Issue 4, 112223.

Dear Dr. Kreiman,
The open access journal Brain Sciences (ISSN 2076-3425, IF 2.8) is pleased to announce a new Special Issue entitled "Brain Boosting: Recent Advances in Neurostimulation on Cognitive Functions and Behavioral Performance". The submission deadline is 20 January 2026 and papers may be submitted immediately or at any point until 20 January 2026, as papers will be published on an ongoing basis. For more information on this Special Issue and submission guidelines, please visit the following page: https://www.mdpi.com/si/brainsci/5AQ5U7MNPU.
MDPI offers professional article preparation services (language and figure editing) completed in just 1 day: https://www.mdpi.com/authors/english.
We also invite you to post an early version of your paper on our free preprint platform, Preprints, allowing you to receive feedback from your peers and make your early results citable. For more information or to submit your preprint, visit https://www.preprints.org/about#works.
Please submit your decision on the invitation here 
Kind regards,
Bertha Zhang
Special Issue Editor
Brain Sciences is fully open access. Manuscripts are peer-reviewed and a first decision provided to authors approximately 16.24 days after submission. An Article Processing Charge (APC) of 2200 CHF currently applies to all papers accepted after peer review. You may be entitled to a discount if you have previously received a discount code from Editorial Office or if your institution is a participating member in MDPI’s Institutional Open Access Program (IOAP). headlines: ["Call for papers and deadline extension for HHAI 2025 conference"]
anchors: ["full papers", "call for papers", "working papers", "deadline extension", "double-blind reviewing"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Chiara Natali
To: EUCog General News
Time: 2025-01-15T04:51:37-08:00
Subject: [EUCog News] [CFP] [Deadline Extension] HHAI 2025 - Hybrid
 Human-Artificial Intelligence (June 9-13, 2025, Pisa, Italy)
(Apologies if you receive multiple copies of this CfP)
CALL FOR PAPERS
HHAI 2025 - Hybrid Human-Artificial Intelligence
https://hhai-conference.org/2025/
June 9–13, 2025, Pisa, Italy 
Abstract submission: January 24th, 2025 (Extended)
Paper submission: January 31th, 2025 (Extended)
Submission link: https://easychair.org/my/conference?conf=hhai2025
Hybrid Human-Artificial Intelligence (HHAI) is an international conference 
series that focuses on the study of Artificial Intelligence systems that 
cooperate synergistically, proactively and purposefully with humans, 
amplifying instead of replacing human intelligence. HHAI aims for AI 
systems that work together with humans, emphasizing the need for adaptive, 
collaborative, responsible, interactive and human-centered intelligent 
systems. HHAI systems leverage human strengths and compensate for human 
weaknesses, while taking into account social, ethical and legal 
considerations.
HHAI 2025 will be held on June 9–13, 2025, in Pisa, Italy, and is the 
fourth conference in the series. The HHAI field is driven by developments 
in AI, but it also requires fundamentally new approaches and solutions. 
Thus, we encourage collaborations across research domains such as AI, HCI, 
cognitive and social sciences, philosophy and ethics, complex systems, and 
others. In this fourth international conference, we invite scholars from 
these fields to submit their best original – new as well as in progress – 
works, and visionary ideas on Hybrid Human-Artificial Intelligence.
**Join the HHAI community and keep up with the news:**
Website: https://hhai-conference.org/2025/
Linkedin: https://www.linkedin.com/company/hhai-conference/
X: https://x.com/hhai_conference
Mastodon: https://sigmoid.social/@hhai
IMPORTANT DATES
Abstract submission: January 24th, 2025 (Extended)
Paper submission: January 31th, 2025 (Extended)
Acceptance notification: March 16th, 2025
Camera-ready version: April 13th, 2025 
Conference: June 9-13, 2025
LOCATION
HHAI 2025 will be an in-person, single-track conference organized in Pisa, 
Italy. Workshops and tutorials (9-10 June) will be held at the University 
of Pisa and Scuola Normale Superiore in Pisa, Italy. The main conference 
(11-13 June) will be held at CNR. 
TOPICS
We invite research on different challenges in Hybrid Human-Artificial 
Intelligence. The following list of topics is illustrative, not exhaustive:
- Human-AI interaction, interpretation and collaboration
- Adaptive human-AI co-learning and co-creation
- Learning, reasoning and planning with humans and machines in the loop
- User modeling and personalisation
- Integration of learning and reasoning
- Transparent, explainable, and accountable AI
- Fair, ethical, responsible, and trustworthy AI
- Societal awareness of AI
- Multimodal machine perception of real-world settings
- Social signal processing
- Representations learning for Communicative or Collaborative AI
- Symbolic representations for human-centric AI
- Human-AI Coevolution
- Foundation models and humans
- Human cognition-aware AI
- Decentralized human-AI systems
- Reliability and robustness in human-AI systems
- Applications of hybrid human-AI intelligence
We welcome contributions about all types of technology, from robots and 
conversational agents to multi-agent systems and machine learning models.
PAPER TYPES
In this conference, we wish to stimulate the exchange of novel ideas and 
interdisciplinary perspectives. To do this, we will accept three different 
types of papers:
- Full papers present original, impactful work (12 pages excluding 
references)
- Blue sky papers present visionary ideas to stimulate the research 
community (8 pages excluding references)
- Working papers present work in progress (8 pages excluding references)
Accepted full papers and Blue sky papers will be published in the 
Proceedings of the Fourth International Conference on Hybrid Human-Machine 
Intelligence, in the Frontiers of AI series by IOS Press. Working papers 
can be included in these proceedings, unless the authors request the paper 
to remain unpublished.
REVIEWING PROCESS & SUBMISSION GUIDELINES
Submissions of full, blue-sky, and working papers should be original work 
without substantial overlap with pre-published papers. All submissions 
should adhere to IOS formatting guidelines. Papers should be written in 
English and detailed submission instructions can also be found here.
**Important**
HHAI 2025 will follow a double-blind reviewing process. Thus, submissions 
must exclude all information that might disclose the authors’ names or 
affiliations. 
All studies involving human participants should have received 
human-research ethics consent from the relevant institutions and mention 
this in the paper. 
Work should be submitted in PDF format via Easychair following this link: 
https://easychair.org/my/conference?conf=hhai2025
On acceptance, at least one author should attend the conference. A 
significant contribution is expected from all authors. 
PROGRAM CHAIRS
Chiara Boldrini (IIT-CNR, IT)
Luca Pappalardo (ISTI-CNR, IT)
Andrea Passerini (University of Trento, IT)
Shenghui Wang (University of Twente, NL)
CONFERENCE CHAIRS
Michela Milano (University of Bologna, IT)
Dino Pedreschi (University of Pisa, IT)
Stuart Russell (University of California Berkeley, US)
Ilaria Tiddi (Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam, NL)
CONTACT INFORMATION
For questions, you can reach the program chairs at: 
program@hhai-conference.org
--

headlines: ["Adjust BMM schedule to use recorded Josh Tenenbaum lecture and Zoom Q&A"]
anchors: ["Cogsci 2025", "zoom Q&A", "Lillie Auditorium", "recorded keynote lecture", "BMM afternoon schedule"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Morgan Talbot"
To: bmm_summer2025@mit.edu
Time: 2025-08-17T12:43:24-04:00
Subject: Change to BMM afternoon schedule: Josh Tenenbaum recorded lecture -> Q&A
Hi everyone,
I'm writing to provide an update to our schedule for this afternoon:
   - Josh Tenenbaum is unfortunately unable to join us in person today due
   to urgent family reasons. In lieu of the planned lecture, Josh has
   suggested that we watch his keynote lecture from the Cogsci 2025
   conference, followed by Q&A over zoom. The theme of the talk in his words
   is "the present moment in which AI and Cog Sci are connecting, and how
   these two fields can best interact in building better theories of human
   cognition"
   - We will set up the video of Josh's Cogsci lecture in Lillie at 1:30pm,
   for anyone who would like to optionally watch it together. You can also
   watch the talk separately if you like, at this link
   (it is a whole-day video, Josh's talk starts at 03:16:55)
   - Josh will join us via Zoom for Q&A from 3pm-4:15pm today (in Lillie
   Auditorium). He says he is happy to take questions about the talk or
   anything else anyone wants to talk about - and he also has some slides that
   relate the content of his talk to the brain, if folks are interested.
Sam Gershman's lecture will proceed afterwards at 4:30pm, as planned.
Best,
Morgan
-- 
*Morgan B. Talbot *(he/him)
MD-PhD Candidate, Harvard/MIT Health Sciences and Technology (HST)
mtalbot@mit.edu

Message 1
From: "Boscoboinik, J. Anibal"
To: Boscoboinik, J. Anibal
Time: 2025-05-07T02:56:06+00:00
Subject: Raíces Este-USA - Mayo 2025
Estimados miembros de Raíces Este-USA (incluye Midwest),
Cosas interesantes o a tener en cuenta este mes:
  1.  Workshop INCOIN - Tecnologías Inteligentes en la Interdisciplinariedad. 8 y 9 de mayo de 2025 - este evento, organizado por el CITEDU (Centro de Innovaciones Tecnológicas para la Docencia Universitaria) y la Secretaría Académica, abordará visiones globales sobre tecnologías inteligentes e interdisciplinariedad, con la participación de actores de la academia, el sector privado y organizaciones civiles, para promover el aprendizaje continuo. QRs abajo para registrarse (gracias Horacio por el dato).
  1.  Próxima reunión:
Fecha: Jueves 22 de mayo
Hora: 6:00 PM (hora del Este)
Enlace Zoom: https://bnl.zoomgov.com/j/1600526082?pwd=t1soPOiiPrhKVzz30mOEnRzxoZLLHB.1
Meeting ID: 160 052 6082
Passcode: 842833
Estamos buscando dos voluntarios que nos cuenten durante la reunión brevemente a que se dedican, así nos vamos conociendo mejor. Los dos primero videos ya están la pagina de la red: https://raices-este.us/#videos (gracias Gabriela de Larrañaga y Guillermo Warley por ser los primeros!). La idea es ir grabándolos en nuestras reuniones trimestrales (también podemos recibir videos que quieran grabar de manera asíncrona).
  2.  Fundación Williams. Fundacion que ofrece subsidios para visitas, organizacion de actividades, etc en Argentina. Tiene cosas interesantes para chusmear: https://fundacionwilliams.org.ar/
  3.  Panel Interredes: Diplomacia Cientítica - "Save the date" 28 de mayo. Las Redes de Alemania y EEUU-Este estamos organizando un panel sobre el rol de las Redes (RCAE) como actores de  diplomacia de la ciencia (extensivo a tecnología e innovación). Este evento esta organizado por Horacio Rotstein de nuestro lado. El panel va a ser el miércoles 28 de mayo a las 13:00 (NYC, EDT), 14:00 (ARG), 19:00 (DE), 20:00 (EEST). Va a quedar grabado para que puedan verlo aquellos que se encuentran en husos horarios para los cuales el horario elegido es inconveniente.
Lxs panelistas van a ser:
Karina Pombo (ex directora de relaciones internacionales del MinCyT)
Paz García Calvo (diplomática, actualmente en la embajada argentina en Egipto)
Aldo Boccaccini (coordinador emerito de red de Alemania)
  1.  Ayudando a Bahía Blanca. Varios miembros de nuestra red, y especialmente Horacio Rotstein, han estado participando activamente en actividades para contribuir a paliar la situación luego de la inundación en Bahía Blanca at través de donaciones. Horacio recibió una carta de agradecimiento de la Fundación de la Universidad Nacional del Sur que se extiende a todos los miembros de nuestra red que han contribuido. Asimismo, hay una colecta actualmente para contribuir a la reconstrucción de la UNS, y este es el link para los que deseen contribuir: https://reconstruir.uns.edu.ar/donaciones
No duden en contactarnos si tienen preguntas, sugerencias, o material que consideren de importancia difundir al resto de los miembros de la red.
Saludos cordiales,
Aníbal Boscoboinik
Coordinador Raíces Este-USA
https://raices-este.us/
PS 1: Horas de Oficina Semanales sobre Inserción en el Sistema Estadounidense para Investigadores Argentinos (Gabriela de Larrañaga, Irina Mindlis y Julieta Bonvin Sallago) - todos los miercoles a las 4 pm ET: meet.google.com/axo-kmfi-rzq
PS 2: No se olviden de unirse al chat en Discord para mantener una comunicación más directa: https://discord.gg/QEYRzfpBrZ
PS 3: LinkedIn de la Red: https://www.linkedin.com/company/raices-este-usa/
J. Anibal Boscoboinik
Center for Functional Nanomaterials
Brookhaven National Laboratory
https://orcid.org/0000-0002-5090-7079

headlines: ["Dianna asks me to review student's NE240 project design issues"]
anchors: ["assignment 1 requirements", "simulate human vision", "project design problems", "level of specificity", "evaluation of background"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Hidalgo, Dianna"
To: Gabriel Kreiman
Time: 2025-02-11T16:41:28-05:00
Subject: Fwd: Problem facing for the project design
Do you mind checking this out?
---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Enhui/Mike Li 
Date: Sun, Feb 9, 2025 at 11:25 AM
Subject: Re: Problem facing for the project design
To: , , 
On Sun, Feb 9, 2025 at 11:24 AM Enhui/Mike Li  wrote:
> Dear Dr. Kreiman, Dr. Hidalgo, Teacher Thamma,
>
> I hope this letter finds you well!
>
> I am currently facing some problems in designing the project. I found that
> the projects I wanted to accomplish could be achieved by completing two
> goals. But the design of the second goal (including database, model design)
> may need to change based on the results of the first goal and the process
> of my own learning. I can't detail the second design right now. And I want
> CNN to simulate human vision in a variety of ways, but so far I've only
> come up with one that's holistic processing.
>
>
> I would like to implore for your help in showing me:
>
> 1. How to simulate human vision from other perspectives such as analyzing
> the environmental impact.
>
> 2: I wonder if my sloppy design of my second goal, which will almost
> certainly change in the future, will meet the requirements of Assignment 1.
>
> 3. I also hope to get your evaluation, to see if I, as a student learning
> ML with programming experience and shallow AI experience, can meet my level
> of project design, and on the basis of certain challenges, I can complete
> this task with enough hard work.
>
> 4. Please also give me some insight into the level of specificity in the
> design of this task.
>
> I highly appreciate your help!
>
>
> In the following two attachments, "project design" is the homework I want
> to submit, and it is a very brief introduction of my project design.
> "specific" is my introduction to my project and the small experiments that
> have been designed within it.
>
> As a sophomore majoring in CS, deeply influenced by my parents, I have
> been passionate about biology since junior high school. I hope that this
> semester I can fully achieve my goals from this course and my project, have
> some challenges to myself, and gain some knowledge and understanding of the
> intersection of computer and neurology. Thank you very much for your help!
> Sorry to bother you on Sunday morning!
>
> Best regards,
> Enhui Li
>
>

Go over all the questions in the

Exciting stuff! Talk to you soon!

headlines: ["Confirmation of participation in UCSF BrainMind Science Collective"]
anchors: ["accommodations provided", "transit expenses", "pre events", "dinner with experts", "opening reception"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Diana Saville
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-02-05T14:46:24+00:00
Subject: Confirmation - UCSF BrainMind Science Collective
Dear Gabriel,
We are thrilled to confirm your participation in the *UCSF BrainMind
Science Collective, March 21-23, 2025*. Please look out for your calendar
invitations for the events. Details below:
*Friday, March 21st, 2025*
   - *Pre Events (Day 1)*
      - 10:00 AM Special Topic Breakouts
      - 12:00 PM Lunch Session
      - 2:00 PM Special Topic Breakouts
   - *Opening Reception (Day 1)*
      - 6:00pm - 9:00pm
*Saturday, March 22nd, 2025*
   - *BrainMind Science Collective (Day 2)*
      - UCSF, Mission Bay Conference Center (1675 Owens Street San
      Francisco, CA 94143)
      - 8:00am - 6:00pm
   - *A Feast of Ideas: Dinner with BrainMind Experts*
      - UCSF, Mission Bay Conference Center – same address
      - 6:00pm - 9:00pm
*Sunday, March 23rd, 2025*
   - *BrainMind Science Collective (Day 3)*
      - UCSF, Mission Bay Conference Center – same address
      - 8:00am - 6:00pm
Accommodations will be provided to maximize community building during the
gathering; however, if you prefer to stay somewhere specific, you are
welcome to book alternative lodging at your own expense. As a reminder,
participants are expected to arrange and cover their own transit expenses.
Limited travel grants are available for early-career scientists and those
facing special circumstances—if you need to apply, send me a note.
This gathering is invitation-only. However, we warmly welcome referrals for
participation, guided by your personal discernment of character,
authenticity, and talent. If you know exceptional individuals who would be
a great fit, please email us with your recommendations.
We are happy to help with any questions you have in the meantime - drop us
a line!
Warmly,
Diana, Michael, and the BrainMind team

Message 1
From: "Boscoboinik, J. Anibal"
To: Boscoboinik, J. Anibal
Time: 2025-06-28T19:58:27+00:00
Subject: Actualizaciones RAICES Este USA – Junio 2025
Estimados miembros de Raíces Este-USA (incluye Midwest),
Esperos que se encuentren bien. Le comparto las novedades del mes de junio:
[📢]Ley de Financiamiento Universitario
El Consejo Interuniversitario Nacional (CIN), la Federación Universitaria Argentina (FUA) y el Frente Sindical de Universidades Nacionales invitan a la comunidad universitaria y general a adherir de manera personal al proyecto de Ley de Financiamiento de la Educación Superior que presentaron en la Comisión de Educación del Honorable Cámara de Diputados de la Nación el 28 de mayo.
[✍️] Adhesiones: Formulario
 Situación del financiamiento científico en Argentina – Material compilado por RAICES Alemania
  1.  [📄]  Nota del CIN: “La universidad pública y la ciencia, en crisis profunda”
  2.  [🎥]  Presentaciones de científicos ante el Senado (04/06/25):
     *   Ariel Pereda
     *   Mario Pecheny
     *   Miguel Schiavini
     *   Jorge Geffner
     *   Diego Hurtado
     *   Valeria Levy
  3.  [📜]  Declaración de la Academia Nacional de Ciencias (6/6/25):
 Ver documento
[📚] Nueva Cohorte 2025–2026 de la Diplomatura en Diplomacia Científica – FCNyM, UNLP
Está abierta la inscripción para la próxima cohorte de la Diplomatura de Posgrado en Diplomacia Científica coordinada por Karina Pombo y Sandra Torrusio.
[📅] Inicio: 22 de agosto de 2025
[💻] Modalidad: A distancia
[🧾] Compuesta por 5 cursos independientes (pueden cursarse por separado)
Cronograma:
  *   Curso 1 – Introducción, conceptos y actores (22/8 al 12/9/25)
  *   Curso 2 – Estrategias avanzadas y aplicaciones (24/10 al 14/11/25)
  *   Curso 3 – Comunicación internacional (marzo/abril 2026)
  *   Curso 4 – Diplomacia de la innovación (mayo 2026)
  *   Curso 5 – Bioeconomía y desarrollo regional (junio 2026)
[📩] Más información: programa.diplomacia@gsuite.fcnym.unlp.edu.ar
 Conocé a los miembros de nuestra red
[👉] Segui a Raices Este USA en LinkedIn y descubrí lo que hacen los científicos argentinos de nuestra red: LinkedIn RAICES Este USA (gracias Andrea Capurro!)[🎙️] Video del miembro Román Baravalle. Román nos cuenta a que se dedica, y contesta algunas preguntas durante la ultima reunión de la red (estamos buscando voluntarios para la próxima reunión!): https://youtu.be/XKHcs2iDvrM
[🧪] Solidaridad con Bahía Blanca – Reconstrucción de laboratorios
El Departamento de Física de la Universidad Nacional del Sur sufrió daños devastadores tras las inundaciones del 7 de marzo. Casi todo el equipamiento fue destruido. Se puede colaborar con donaciones:
[💸] https://reconstruir.uns.edu.ar/donaciones
 Contacto: Marcelo Costabel, marcelo.costabel@uns.edu.ar
La carta completa al respecto que nos enviaron de la Asociación Física Argentina vá adjunta este mensaje.
No duden en contactarnos si tienen preguntas, sugerencias, o material que consideren de importancia difundir al resto de los miembros de la red.
Saludos cordiales,
Aníbal Boscoboinik
Coordinador Raíces Este-USA
https://raices-este.us/

PS 2: No se olviden de unirse al chat en Discord para mantener una comunicación más directa: https://discord.gg/QEYRzfpBrZ

headlines: ["Mengmi Zhang proposes research collaboration on dog vocalization recordings"]
anchors: ["on-site visit", "dog vocalizations", "naturalistic settings", "research grant", "visual and audio recordings"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Zhang Mengmi (Asst Prof)"
To: happy_dogtraining@yahoo.com.sg
Time: 2025-09-11T06:06:29+00:00
Subject: Research Collaboration on Dog Vocalization Study
Dear Dog Training Team,
My name is Mengmi Zhang, Assistant Professor in College of Computing and Data Science at NTU. Our team plans to study dog vocalizations in naturalistic settings using Artificial Intelligence (AI), collecting visual and audio recordings to better understand how dogs communicate.
We are planning to apply for a research grant next year (e.g., AI for Science / CRP) to support this work and are very interested in a research collaboration with you. We would love to arrange a short meeting and on-site visit to discuss whether it’s possible to collect recordings at your facility in a non-intrusive, welfare-friendly way.
We would acknowledge your support in publications and share research insights that may benefit your work with dogs.
Please let us know if you are open to research collaborations. Thank you for your time, and we look forward to your reply.
Best,
Mengmi
Nanyang assistant professor and PI of Deep NeuroCognition Lab
College of Computing and Data Science
Nanyang Technological University
Lab website: https://a0091624.wixsite.com/deepneurocognition-1
CONFIDENTIALITY: This email is intended solely for the person(s) named and may be confidential and/or privileged. If you are not the intended recipient, please delete it, notify us and do not copy, use, or disclose its contents.
Towards a sustainable earth: Print only when necessary. Thank you.

headlines: ["Welcome and onboarding requests for AI Lab for Startups program"]
anchors: ["Innovation Committee presentations", "Core Mentor meetings", "quarterly milestones", "introductory Zoom call", "pitch deck and bios"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Kleiman, Debi"
To:
  - Madan, Spandan
  - Gabriel Kreiman
Time: 2025-01-28T00:55:54+00:00
Subject: Welcome to the AI Lab for Startups!
Gabriel and Spandan,
Welcome to the program! We're thrilled to have you join us and look forward to supporting your venture through our resources, mentorship, and community of fellow academic founders.
Let me outline our key program components:
Programming, Mentors & Updates
- We host monthly/bi-monthly Zoom sessions covering essential entrepreneurial topics with expert speakers (highly recommended, though not mandatory)
- Each quarter, you'll set and work toward 3 specific milestones. Quarterly presentations to our Innovation Committee, where you'll share progress on your milestones, are required to maintain your spot in the program.
- Within the next week, I'll connect you with your Core Mentor, who will meet with you at least twice monthly (frequency can be adjusted based on your needs).
Next Steps
1. Please send me:
   - Your latest executive summary or pitch deck
   - A brief pitch (2-3 sentences)
   - Short bios for team members
2. I'll begin scheduling our regular sessions. Could you confirm if both team members will be participating fully? Also, please let me know if I may share your contact information with our mentors.
3. I'd love to schedule a Zoom call to walk you through all our available resources and how to access them. We can also dive into where you think you need the most help right now so that I can line up the most relevant mentors. You can book a time that works best for you through my Calendly link: https://calendly.com/meetwithdebikleiman/intromtg
Looking forward to supporting your entrepreneurial journey!
Best,
Debi
Debi Kleiman | The AI Lab for Startups | Digital Data Design Institute at Harvard  | HARVARD BUSINESS SCHOOL

On behalf of *NTU World of Wisdom*, the knowledge-outreach platform of the

This year’s theme, *RE: Human*, explores what it means to be human in an
age of rapid technological change. Through talks that reflect how people
adapt, resist, and reinvent themselves amid evolving digital landscapes,

solidarity – encouraging us to reconnect with our shared humanity while
embracing the future. More about our team and speakers can be found
