headlines: ["Missed AA 4376 JFK\u2013BOS connection and alternative bus travel to Boston"]
anchors: ["luggage traveled separately", "bus to Boston", "missed connection", "standby list", "gate already closed"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Raul Kreiman
To: gabriel
Time: 2025-08-24T18:46:22-03:00
Subject: Vuelo AA 4376 JFK-BOS dated August 1 . Departure time was 8.29 am.
El vuelo conectaba con el vuelo AA 954 EZE-JFK dated July 31, 2025
cuyo horario estimado de vuelo era 7 am
Observaciones
1. El vuelo AA954 llegó con varios minutos de demora; Además, estábamos en
la fila 37.
2. Habíamos solicitado asistencia para Liidia, más aún teniendo en cuenta
el lapso corto de que disponíamos para abordar el vuelo 4376 (operated by
Republic Airways as American Eagle)
Si bien la asistencia nos  permitió pasar sin demoras por Immigration y
luego por Customs,  luego se demoró exageradamente porque tenia que buscar
otra pasajera y  llevar simultaneamente 2 sillas de ruedas, esperar  mucho
tiempo ascensores para poder llevarlas y hacer paradas innecesarias. Viendo
el *limitado tiempo disponible,* lo lógico hubiera sido  que la Asistente
informara esta situación a AA, pidiendo que nos esperaran un par de
minutos. Pero no lo hicieron.
3. AA no tenía lugar en los vuelos siguientes de Aug 1 pero en la gate no
tuvieron la amabilidad de conseguirnos un vuelo en una compañía alternativa
ese día.
3. Llegamos al gate un par de minutos antes de las 8.29 am, pero la puerta
del avión ya estaba cerrada y nos impidieron abordar el vuelo.
4. Estuvimos esperando casi 6 horas junto a la gate, a ver si podíamos
abordar mediante la lista de espera en alguno de los vuelos siguientes. la
espera fue inutil.
5. Nuestro hijo nos consiguió pasajes en bus con el que llegamos a Boston a
las 9pm.
Gastos y otros:
5.1. No usamos el vuelo 4376 pero lo pagamos.
5.2 . Taxi hasta el lugar de salida del bus a Boston más el costo de los 2
pasajes correspondientes.
5.3 Nuestro equipaje viajó a Boston en el vuelo 4376 - FELIZMENTE!. Qué
hubiera pasado si no hubiera sido asi? - y tuvimos que irlo a buscar al
Aeropuerto Logan a nuestro regreso
5.4. Perdimos casi todo el dia - Aug 1- por este caso de mala praxis.

headlines: ["Bank of America to cancel credit card Bill Pay payments starting September 13"]
topics: ["Bank of America personal credit card payments change"]
anchors: ["recurring payments", "Pay & Transfer", "credit card eBills", "external account", "Bill Pay Service canceled"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Bank of America"
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-08-14T12:40:31-06:00
Subject: Starting September 13, we’re changing the way you make payments to your personal credit card in Mobile and Online Banking
BANK OF AMERICA
IMPORTANT INFORMATION
+++ Reminder: Starting September 13, we're changing the way you pay your personal Bank of America credit card - here's what you need to know +++
We're changing the way you make credit card payments in Mobile(1) and Online Banking. The enhancements we're making to Pay & Transfer will allow you to have better control over your payments.
As a part of these changes, starting September 13, you'll no longer be able to use our Bill Pay Service to pay your personal Bank of America credit card. 
We'll cancel any one-time or recurring payments set up by you or another person on your behalf to your personal Bank of America credit card that are scheduled to process in the Bill Pay Service on or after September 13. Additionally, any one-time or recurring payments you scheduled to process on or after September 13 in the Bill Pay Service to pay another person's personal Bank of America credit card will be canceled. 
If you do cancel your payment(s) and want to schedule a one-time payment to process before September 13, you can do so in Mobile or Online Banking by selecting Pay & Transfer and clicking Transfer.
Pay & Transfer
Here's what else you need to know
- If you have any scheduled payments set to process on or after September 13, you should cancel them. To cancel a payment, go to our Bill Pay Payment Center, locate your scheduled payment and click Cancel. 
Bill Pay Payment Center
- If you receive personal Bank of America credit card eBills and payment reminders through the Bill Pay Service today, they'll be canceled. You can enroll in comparable alerts at bankofamerica.com/alerts.
bankofamerica.com/alerts
- You'll still be able to use the Bill Pay Service to pay your other bills, but your personal Bank of America credit card will no longer be listed as an eligible payee.
Here are some of the enhancements we're making
Starting on September 13, you'll notice some changes in Mobile and Online Banking:
- To make it easier for you, everything you need to pay and manage your card will be under the Pay & Transfer tab. 
- In Pay & Transfer, all of your payment activity will be in one place.
- You'll be able to set up recurring payments that better align to your statement dates and balances. 
- You can use an external account in Pay & Transfer to pay your credit card.
We're here to help
If you have any questions, please call the number on the back of your card. 
Thank you for being our client.
(1) Mobile Banking requires that you download the Mobile Banking app and may not be available for select mobile devices. Message and data rates may apply.
This communication is for informational purposes only and is not an attempt to collect a debt.
Bank of America and the Bank of America logo are registered trademarks of Bank of America Corporation.

relationship with us.

hebreo en nuestra institución.
Gracias a una alianza colaborativa que hemos alcanzado con la Organización
Sionista Mundial (OSM), nuestra comunidad educativa -familias, Alumni y personal
de ORT- podrá acceder a cursos de hebreo, con una propuesta de excelencia.
La OSM ha desarrollado un sistema de enseñanza intensiva de la lengua hebrea,
reconocido internacionalmente por su metodología, y utilizado en diversas
comunidades. A través de este programa, ofreceremos:
* Dos cursos de nivel inicial, uno en sede Almagro, los martes de 18:00 a 20:15
hs., y otro en sede Belgrano, los jueves de 18:00 a 20:15 hs. Los mismos
tienen cupos limitados e iniciarán a partir del martes 1 de abril.
* La OSM dictará las clases, brindará asesoramiento, capacitación y el material
didáctico necesario. Además, certificará el nivel alcanzado por quienes
completen el curso y aprueben los exámenes.
Para anotarse, los invitamos a completar el formulario de inscripción, haciendo
clic en el siguiente botón:
Como siempre, ante cualquier duda o consulta, estamos a disposición.
Un cálido saludo,
ORT ARGENTINA
 Para dejar de recibir estos
mensajes utiliza el siguiente enlace:
Este mensaje fue enviado a gkreiman@gmail.com por Comunicación Institucional - ORT Argentina.

headlines: ["Receive Super Age Longevity Quiz results and recommendations"]
anchors: ["stress box breathing practice", "longevity quiz score 85.21", "sleep tracking suggestions", "exercise and recovery tips", "eating habits guidance"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Super Age"
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-02-15T10:29:11+11:00
Subject: Your Super Age Longevity Quiz Results
Strength training supports your entire nervous system, the secret to melatonin, optimism’s link to longevity, and more!
Your Super Age Longevity Quiz Results
Score: 85.21
Thank you so much for taking the Super Age Longevity Quiz! Below, you will find a range of health pointers and suggestions that can boost your lifespan based on your answers to our quiz questions.
We believe that around 80% of our personal health outcomes are a direct result of our choices, which is great! It means we have the power to make positive change.
Please note, this content is for educational and entertainment purposes only. Nothing you read online should be substituted for the advice of a good, trusted doctor.
Top Priority: Eating Habits
“You are what you eat.” An oldie but a goodie when it comes to longevity. Looking at your quiz results, we can see you describe your diet as "A mix of everything (moderately healthy)"
You’re already building a strong foundation with healthy habits—now let’s take it to the next level. Once you've covered the basics, staying hydrated, packing your meals with high-fiber antioxidant and phytonutrient-rich vegetables, and swapping processed foods for whole foods, consider adding these to your nutrition goals:
Hydrate more: You know this, but we all need reminders. Even mild dehydration can impair energy and focus.
Don't Skimp on Whole Fruit: Natural sugars paired with fiber help regulate blood sugar levels, reducing the risk of diabetes.
Practice Mindful Eating: Slow down, savor each bite, and pay attention to your body’s hunger and fullness cues. Mindful eating can prevent overeating and enhance digestion, making every meal more satisfying
Shift dessert to earlier in the day, like mid-afternoon. This timing allows your body to process the glucose spike more effectively and use it as fuel rather than storing it.
Consider wearing a continuous glucose monitor (CGM). This small device tracks how your body responds to different foods in real time, offering personalized insights into your glucose trends. Are certain snacks spiking your blood sugar more than you thought? Is your go-to smoothie keeping you energized or causing an afternoon crash? A CGM can help you fine-tune your nutrition choices for peak energy and longevity. Try it for a month.
The journey to optimized nutrition isn’t about perfection; it’s about curiosity and refinement. With every tweak, you’re aligning your habits with your goals for a longer, healthier, more vibrant life.
Top Priority: Exercise
When it comes to exercise, we think momentum is key. Whatever your favorite way to get moving is, just keep doing it. Seeing as you exercise "Almost every day or more", here's what we think:
You get a gold star! Remember to stretch, and, when really pushing yourself, keep in mind that longevity-minded athletes take recovery just as seriously as the sport or workout itself. Use a foam roller to massage those muscles, hop in the sauna when you can, and stay consistent in how you maintain your output/recuperation balance.
Curious about new ways to track your performance? Use a wearable tracker to get data on daily steps and sleep quality and to time our workouts.
Bonus: Make sure you're getting enough electrolytes in your diet to stay properly hydrated before, during, and after your workout.
Top Priority: Sleep
Well done! It sounds like you make sleep a priority, given that you sleep 8+ hours per night. On the rare occasion you can’t seem to doze off, sometimes it can be best to just “give up,” get out of bed, and do something entirely different for a while before returning to the pillow. For us, a warm cup of herbal tea or a little yoga can do the trick. Want to gather data about your sleep quality? We use trackers like Whoop and Oura to get daily feedback on how well we slept.
Bonus: We’d love to hear your go-to strategies for consistently sleeping well! Drop us a line at:  editor@superage.com [mailto:info@weareageist.com].
Top Priority: Stress
Just like sleep, stress can have widespread effects on our mental health, immune system, and overall disposition. Seeing as your life is Somewhat negatively impacted by stress, here’s the scoop.
Even if stress doesn't seem to affect you much, it is still crucial to have stress management systems in place for long-term wellness and overall heart health. Next time you feel a bit frazzled, start lowering your stress levels by incorporating daily mindfulness practices, such as box breathing
This simple practice can switch your body out of fight or flight mode––and is even  used by Navy Seals [https://time.com/4316151/breathing-technique-navy-seal-calm-focused/] ( they call it tactical breathing) to stay calm and focused. Here’s how: Breathe out fully, emptying your lungs. Then, inhale through your nose for a slow count of four, feeling your lungs and stomach expand. Hold for four. Exhale for four. Hold again for four. Repeat this cycle for three to four rounds to reset and refocus. It works.
Thanks again for taking our Longevity Quiz!
Today, we covered the top few pillars of longevity. At Super Age, we know we all have the power to reframe our reality and forge our future. Explore  The Ultimate Guide to Super Aging [https://www.superage.com/ultimate-guide-to-super-aging] for more on how to live long and healthy at any age. Check your inbox every week for The Mindset, where we unpack the latest research, stories, and practices that enhance your journey, tend to your heart, inspire your creativity, and help you imagine what’s possible when you tap into your dynamic potential.
Were you forwarded this email?  Sign up here [https://www.superage.com/]
We want to hear from you! How can we help you Super Age?
Reply [mailto:editor@superage.com] to this email and tell us what you want to read about.
This issue of Super Age was written, edited, and produced by David Stewart and Heather Hurlock.
Privacy [https://www.superage.com/privacy] &  Terms [https://www.superage.com/terms] |  Contact [mailto:info@superage.com] |  Partner With Us [mailto:info@superage.com]
Copyright © 2024
All rights reserved

3419 Via Lido, Suite 657
Newport Beach, CA 92663 [http://www.superage.com]

headlines: ["Susan Albright criticizes rhetoric about transgender youth in Ward 4 race", "Susan Albright endorses candidates for Newton City Council", "Susan Albright endorses candidates for Newton School Committee races", "Susan Albright outlines prior parking policy proposals that did not gain traction", "Susan Albright requests a yes vote on repealing the overnight winter parking ban", "Vibrant Newton publishes 2025 City Council endorsements and promotes Susan Albright\u2019s candidacy"]
topics: ["Newton School Committee races", "2025 Newton City Council election", "Newton winter parking ban repeal ballot question", "Newton parking reform proposals"]
people: ["Linda Swaine", "Maria Greenberg", "Josh Krintzman", "Jonathan Greene", "Gary Miller", "Victor Lee", "Susan Albright <susansophia.albright@84417105.mailchimpapp.com>", "Sean Roche", "Ben Schlesinger", "Cyrus Dahmubed"]
anchors: ["hate teachers", "Wards 2 and 3", "city council endorsements", "Area Council debate", "parking overlay district", "ballot question", "year-round parking", "winter parking ban", "yes vote", "narrow streets review", "school committee races", "campaign tone", "Ward 4 race", "Ward 4 At-Large", "Ward 6 At-Large", "marginalized students", "Councilor-at-Large Ward 2", "campaign paid for", "Vibrant Newton\u2019s endorsements", "vote for me", "parking policy", "transgender youth", "trial program", "core values", "Newton\u2019s educators", "2025 City Council election", "Facebook posts", "contested races", "snow emergency"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Susan Albright
To: =?utf-8?Q?Gabriel=20Kreiman?=
Time: 2025-10-22T12:21:16+00:00
Subject: Leadership and Parking
View this email in your browser 
** 🏙️ A Fairer Newton: Smarter Parking Policies and Leaders Who Share Our Values
Let's Repeal the Winter Parking Ban — Keep the Snow Emergency in Place
The ballot question to repeal the winger ban is something I've worked on for six years.
Let’s start with reassurance: the Snow Emergency Winter Parking Ban will remain in place regardless of the outcome of this vote. Safety isn’t up for debate — fairness and common sense are.
Many residents tell me the overnight winter parking ban places an unfair burden on them. Elderly couples and single parents without driveways face the same challenge — finding a parking space, often blocks from home.
One mother told me she had to leave her children alone while she parked and walked back through the cold and dark, hoping everything would be fine. Seniors face similar risks. Renters often have only one driveway spot, forcing them to pay high prices for winter parking. Families in older homes without driveways sometimes end up paving over front yards, just to comply.
Policies should fit the realities of residents’ lives. A modern, flexible approach can protect safety and fairness — ensuring clear streets during storms while respecting how people actually live.
Over the years, I’ve proposed:
* A parking overlay district in neighborhoods most affected by university parking
* A trial program in parts of Wards 2 and 3 to test more flexible approaches
* A review of narrow streets to allow year-round parking on only one side, where needed for safety
None of these ideas gained traction in the Council, and that's why I believe the repeal deserves your yes vote to make the Council pay attention.   When this passes, the Council and Traffic Council will revisit parking policy, and I’ll work hard to ensure practical, balanced parking rules that serve everyone in Newton.
** 🌳 My take on Our Community Values
My endorsements in this election reflect what I believe to be Newton’s core values — shaped by growing up here, raising my family here, and  a review across city departments, including the school department in the 2025-26 budget  mission statements, which show some clear shared themes:
* Equity and inclusion — ensuring access, dignity, and fairness for all residents
* Sustainability — environmentally responsible infrastructure and fiscal health
* Public safety and quality of life — responsive services and well-maintained spaces
* Accountability and transparency — professionalism and collaboration in city government
Together, these values describe Newton’s vision of a safe, fair, and sustainable community that works for everyone.
** 🗳️ City Council Endorsements
In this election, I’m supporting candidates in contested races who embody these values — people who lead with integrity, respect, and a genuine commitment to inclusion and good governance.
* Ward 6 At-Large: Sean Roche (https://www.seanroche.org/)
* Ward 4 At-Large: Cyrus Dahmubed (https://www.cyrus4newton.org/) and Josh Krintzman (https://www.facebook.com/krintzmanforcitycouncil/)
* Ward 5 (Ward Councilor Race): Gary Miller (https://miller4newton.org/)
* Ward 1 (Ward Councilor Race): Maria Greenberg   (her opponent withdrew but is still on the ballot)
The third candidate in the Ward 4 race has made public comments showing a lack of understanding and empathy toward transgender youth. He states that his Facebook posts were simply a way to learn more about transgender kids.  Here are some of his clarifying statements in the Newton Beacon (https://www.newtonbeacon.org/chaimanis-takes-heat-for-facebook-comments-regarding-protections-for-transgender-students/) : “I have learned that some of the ways I worded my concerns were hurtful. That was never my intention, and I am sorry for any pain or harm I caused." His remarks at the Area Council debate (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZNINt4sK5f4)  (his comments start at minute 40:49 of the recording) didn’t clarify what, if anything, he has learned. Transgender kids are more likely to be bullied than to cause harm to others.  We need leaders who understand that trans kids (and others who are marginalized)  need support and protection, not skepticism.
Josh and Cyrus will support our values, supporting marginalized students as well as supporting our kids and teachers.
** 🎓 The School Committee Races
I’m deeply concerned about the tone of this year’s School Committee campaigns. Some of the rhetoric has become personal and divisive — and that’s not who we are as a community.
A School Committee race should be about what matters most — our students, our teachers, and the future of Newton’s schools. It’s about electing people who listen, collaborate, and focus on helping every child succeed. The committee’s job isn’t politics — it’s working with the Superintendent, setting smart policies, and making sure every student in every school has access to a great education in a supportive, inclusive environment. That’s what Newton’s families expect and deserve.
I’m troubled by claims that certain candidates — or that I myself — “hate teachers.”  As someone who served on the School Committee for eight years, including four on the negotiations committee, I have enormous respect for Newton’s educators. Disagreeing about policy or candidates isn’t the same as devaluing teachers.
Those spreading that message are deepening divisions that we must work to heal if we want our schools — and our city — to thrive.
Here are the candidates I’m supporting in contested races:
* Ward 2: Linda Swaine (https://www.swainforschools.com/)
* Ward 5: Ben Schlesinger (https://ben4newton.com/)
* Ward 6: Jonathan Greene (https://www.jonathan4newton.com/)
* Ward 8: Victor Lee (https://www.victor4newton.com/)
I’ve known Jonathan and Ben since they were 5 years old. They’re thoughtful, honest, and deeply committed to reflecting Newton’s values. Each of these candidates cares about and respects our teachers, our students, and the strength of our public schools.
** In Closing
Newton’s strength has always been its people — thoughtful, compassionate residents who believe in fairness and community. Whether it’s parking reform, inclusive leadership, or supporting our schools, we can and should act with empathy and common sense.
Thank you for caring, voting, and helping to keep Newton a city that works for everyone.
** 🟢 P.S.
Here are Vibrant Newton’s Endorsements for the 2025 City Council election:
👉 https://www.vibrantnewton.org/2025endorsements.html
** 🟣 P.P.S.
Please vote for me too: SUSAN ALBLRIGHT COUNCILOR-AT-LARGE WARD 2!!!!
P.P.S.
Paid for by the Committee to Elect Susan Albright.
============================================================
** Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/susan.albright.7798/)
** Website (https://susanalbright.org)

Dear Gabriel, We’re delighted you’ve been inspired to enter the 2026 TCS London Marathon Ballot. Important: please don’t enter the ballot more than once as this will cancel all your applications. The ballot is a completely random draw (just like the National Lottery) and we’ll let you know if you’ve secured a place by July 2025. If you have any questions about your application or the ballot, please read our FAQs. In the meantime, for news, training tips and chances to win a place in the 2026 TCS London Marathon through our partners and sponsors, follow @LondonMarathon on Facebook, Instagram, Strava and TikTok.  Thanks again for your interest in the 2026 TCS London Marathon! We wish you the best of luck in the ballot. Best wishes,The TCS London Marathon Team

headlines: ["Alicia Bowman shares endorsements and voter guide for Newton municipal election"]
anchors: ["voter guide", "school committee", "municipal election", "city council", "contested races"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Alicia Bowman
To: =?utf-8?Q?Gabriel?=
Time: 2025-09-19T20:05:16+00:00
Subject: My Endorsements for Newton's November Elections
** Supporting Great Candidates
** Upcoming Municipal Election on November 4th
Dear Gabriel
You may have noticed some signs around town.  While there may be fewer signs than in some years, it is indeed election season. And while there are only a handful of contested races, each of these races is important.
The actions we take at a local level are very important to address the climate, housing, education, and our quality of life.
Focusing just on the contested elections, I support the following candidates because I believe each demonstrates the skills, work ethic, and leadership necessary to help Newton address its increasingly complex issues.
Printable List of My Endorsements To Bring to the Polls (https://mcusercontent.com/c8105bb95c80aca3d3c333d1d/files/8dbc8c6b-828b-cefc-5cbc-1f17dfa6f55f/_voter_guide_2025_1_.pdf)
Contested At-Large City Council Races
At-Large Councilors are elected by the whole city and voters can vote for two candidates per ward
Ward 4:
Josh Krintzman
Josh Krintzman has been a positive voice for Newton and his Ward 4 constituents for many years and has served the City Council for eight years including as the Chair of the Programs and Services Committee. He has been a strong champion for climate action, housing and the schools. And very importantly recognizes that reasonable and appropriate development is essential for building a fiscally sustainable future, as a diverse, inclusive and accessible community.  You can learn more about Josh at his website:  https://www.joshkrintzman.com/
Cyrus Dahmubed
Cyrus Dahmubed is a fresh voice in Newton politics, but he is also a lifelong Newton resident ready to step up to serve his community.  As an architect and urban planner, his professional skills will be invaluable to the City Council, especially on the more complicated and contentious issues the Council deals with concerning land use and village center projects. His experience in community engagement for design informs his "listen first, then design solutions together" approach to getting work done and solving problems collaboratively. You can read more about Cyrus at his website: https://www.cyrus4newton.org/.
Ward 6:
Sean Roche
I have worked closely with Sean Roche on committees related to transportation and housing during my many years as an advocate in Newton. He is thoughtful, inclusive and fact-based and has decades of experience working collaboratively for better solutions. Sean understands the need to develop housing options across stages of life and the economic spectrum and that housing is one of the most effective steps Newton can take to address the climate crisis. And to support people of all ages, Newton must make significant improvements in transportation and mobility and that housing and better transportation options are key to sustainable, vibrant village centers. You can learn more about Sean at his website: https://www.seanroche.org/.
Contested Ward City Council Races
Ward Councilors are elected only by the voters who live in their ward and voters can vote for one candidate per ward
Ward 5:
K. Garrett Miller
K. Garrett Miller, more commonly known as Garry, is a longtime Newton resident who is ready to do even more to give back to the community he loves, with constituent services being his #1 focus. His decades of work as a software engineer in the healthcare industry means he has built strong communication skills and is comfortable navigating complex environments. Garry supports a more open, transparent and accountable city government and believes we can build consensus on the major issues: supporting great public education, repairing our roads and other infrastructure, improving our parks, and working on climate transition and mitigation all while putting the city budget  on a more sustainable, long-term course. With so many costs out of the city's control, the more dependable avenue is to attract more economic activity by making the city a more attractive place to do business and by allowing more development, both commercial and residential. Garry is committed to being a councilor who listens
(and hears). You can learn more about Garry at his website: https://miller4newton.org/
Contested School Committee Races
School Committee Members are elected by the whole city and voters can vote for one candidate per ward
Ward 5:
Jenna Miara
Jenna Miara has the independent voice, critical experience and the passion of a NPS parent the Newton School Committee needs for the years ahead. She has worked with communities to solve tough problems as a public interest lawyer, a policy advocate, and a nonprofit leader. Jenna has the experience of collective bargaining both as an employer and a union member, and she is committed to building a healthy and productive relationship with the unions. Jenna supports digital health and balance, including by reducing cell phone and social media use by students in school and by improving the digital literacy programming Learn more about Jenna at her website: https://www.jenna4newton.org/home.
Ward 6:
Mali Brodt
Mali Brodt is an educator, mental-health counselor and a passionate NPS parent who is seeking to improve Newton schools for our children and the city. She has experience that matters (both in the classroom and working with vulnerable students) and is an independent voice. All of this will greatly benefit the Newton School Committee's work in the years to come. Mali has broad support from NPS parents, former School Committee members and experienced educators. You can learn more about Mali at her website: https://www.mali4newton.org/.
Printable List of My Endorsements To Bring to the Polls (https://mcusercontent.com/c8105bb95c80aca3d3c333d1d/files/8dbc8c6b-828b-cefc-5cbc-1f17dfa6f55f/_voter_guide_2025_1_.pdf)
I hope that you have found my thoughts on these great candidates helpful and that you will consider supporting them as well.
All the best,
More Information from The League of Women Voters Newton (https://lwvnewton.org/next-election-november-4-2025-newton-municipal-election/)
https://us20.forward-to-friend.com/forward?u=c8105bb95c80aca3d3c333d1d&id=98b80e16af&e=5ebb4836db Forward to a friend (https://us20.forward-to-friend.com/forward?u=c8105bb95c80aca3d3c333d1d&id=98b80e16af&e=5ebb4836db)

headlines: ["Campaign email from John Chaimanis requesting Newton voters' support"]
anchors: ["vote by mail in ballot", "learn more about issues", "help email campaign", "campaign trail photos", "Ward 4 At Large candidate"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: John Chaimanis
To: GABRIEL
Time: 2025-10-30T20:19:27+00:00
Subject: Head, Heart and Rolled Up Sleeves
Endorsed by: Marc Laredo, Lenny Gentile, John Oliver, Tarik
Lucas, Pam Wright, Julia Malakie, Randy Block, Rena Getz, Alan
Lobovits, Stephen Farrell, Paul Levy, Chris Markiewicz, Paul
Coletti, David Micley, Margaret Albright
Dear Newton Voters:
I'd like to share a little bit more about me, as you make your
decisions this coming Tuesday, November 4th.
I am the son of an immigrant father and a single working mother
who instilled in me the values of looking for good in everyone,
giving back, and hard work.
Anyone who knows me, knows that I fight for social justice in
education, against poverty, and for our common home—the Earth.
While I was not born in Newton, my three children are fifth
generation Newtonians. My wife, Gina Marzilli, and I worked hard
to move to Newton to raise our family here because we know just
how truly special this city is. Our kids attend the Newton Public
Schools because we believe in public education, and we live in a
multigenerational household, because we believe in taking care of
family.
I want to continue my lifetime of service by offering the City
Council my proven experience as a business owner, finance
professional, and clean energy leader.
After earning a degree in finance, I turned down Wall Street to
volunteer-teach science and math to middle schoolers in Roxbury.
I then co-founded a school in inner-city Boston (photo at the
bottom), where I managed all business and operations. Education
had been my gift; giving it back became my duty. In 2005, I
redirected my passion for greater impact - fighting climate
change, which affects all of humanity. A decade ago, I founded a
clean energy company that has already financed projects producing
enough clean energy to power over 25,000 homes.
My record shows I deliver measurable results. I will bring
financial expertise to the City Council - an essential skill that
is underrepresented on the Council today.
As your representative, I will work hard, I will learn, and I
will grow. I will listen to residents, strengthen transparency,
and ground decisions in data and community input.
I humbly ask for your vote,
John Chaimanis, Ward 4 At Large Candidate
-->Learn More About Where John Stands on the Issues 
Learn More About Where John Stands on the Issues (
www.johnchaimanis.org )
Experience Matters
If I've earned your vote...
1) VOTE NOW via mail in Ballot, or VOTE Tuesday Nov 4th.
2) If you think I would be a good addition to the City Council,
be sure to tell your friends.
3) If you want to help: email chaimanisatlarge@gmail.com 
Some fun from the campaign trail...
Finishers of the Paddy's 5K Road Race
Window painting in our village centers
More village fun.
October in Newton means Paddy's Road Race and window painting.
Thank you to Paddy's, Athletes Unlimited, and all the local
businesses who make these traditions possible every year.
Onward!
John
johnchaimanis.org 
chaimanisatlarge@gmail.com 
Endorsed by: Marc Laredo, Lenny Gentile, John Oliver, Tarik
Lucas, Pam Wright, Julia Malakie, Randy Block, Rena Getz, Alan
Lobovits, Stephen Farrell, Paul Levy, Chris Markiewicz, Paul
Coletti, David Micley, Margaret Albright, Newton Firefighter's
Union

headlines: ["PTSO requests volunteers and donations for Newton North post-prom Celebration"]
people: ["Vicki Spetter", "I", "Holly Raynes", "Celebration 2025 Appeal to Parents & Guardians from ALL Grades <celebration@northptso.org>"]
anchors: ["Celebration walk-through", "post-senior prom event", "volunteer roles", "gift cards for prizes", "monetary donation"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Celebration 2025 Appeal to Parents & Guardians from ALL Grades
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-05-28T16:29:57+00:00
Subject: Help Needed for Celebration!
You'll have a senior before you know it...
View this email in your browser 
Calling all Junior Parents & Guardians!
It's our turn to "pay it forward" on Thursday, June 1!
MANY volunteers are still needed--
especially chaperones and clean-up crew
Each year, the Newton North parent community runs a fun-filled post-senior prom event that keeps our students safe on one of the riskiest nights for teen driving. In 2022, more than 90 percent of the senior class joined us for Celebration, where they enjoyed a variety of entertainment, music, food, and prizes--all at no charge to them. Celebration 2023 (https://web.northptso.org/site/celebration-2023/) brings about a fantastic transformation of the public areas of the school, and it takes many volunteers and a lot of money to execute.
Parents/guardians in all grades are needed to pull off this important prevention event*. For those of us who don't have a senior, this is our opportunity to
* See our friends and make new ones
* Get an insider's view of Celebration before our students attend in two years
* Help make Newton the kind of safe community we want to live in
Here are three fantastic ways to support Celebration with a click:
1. Volunteer here. (https://www.signupgenius.com/go/20f094eadaa23a3f58-celebration4#/)  Invite a friend to join you for a few hours of volunteering!
2. Make a monetary donation here. (https://www.paypal.com/donate/?hosted_button_id=KUKMFE4RVQE5J&source=qr4)
3. Donate gift cards for the prize drawing table.  100 gift cards are still needed to entice seniors! (Gift Cards can be dropped off at Beals House (attn: Una Simmons)
All invited: Celebration walk-through on Thursday, June 1, 8:00-9:00 p.m.
Remember, it takes a village...thank you for your support!!
Best regards,
Holly Raynes, Vicki Spetter Class of 2025 PTSO Liaisons
Email: class_liaisons_2025@northptso.org 
Facebook: Newton North H.S. Class of 2025 Parents & Guardians (https://www.facebook.com/groups/1454599364894423)
*Most seniors do not want their parents at this party, which is why we need non-senior parents to set up, decorate, chaperone, serve food, and clean up!
============================================================
Copyright © 2025 Newton North PTSO, All rights reserved.
 You received this email because you opted in with Newton North High School PTSO.
Our mailing address is:
Newton North PTSO
457 Walnut Street
Newton, MA 02460
USA
Want to change how you receive these emails?
You can ** update your preferences

headlines: ["Announcement of world premiere of film 'Parting the Waters'"]
anchors: ["Rhode Island International Film Festival", "Parting the Waters", "film teaser", "world premiere", "buy tickets"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: "Maccabi USA"
To: Gabriel Kreiman
Time: 2025-07-31T19:59:42-04:00
Subject: Don't Miss the World Premier of "Parting the Waters" on Friday, August 8 at RI Int'l Film Festival!
World Premiere: Parting the Waters
Rhode Island International Film Festival on August 8
We are excited to announce that
Parting the Waters, directed by Michele Kuvin Kupfer, Marc Levy, and Marc Solomon, will have its world premiere at the Rhode Island International Film Festival on
Friday, August 8 at 6 pm!
If you can make it to Providence next week, you don't want to miss this inspiring story of trauma, hope, and courage told against the backdrop of the 1981 and 2022 Maccabiah.
Overview:
Michele Kuvin Kupfer, a member of the 1980 Israeli Olympic swim team, sets out––four decades after her final race––to reunite her old teammates and compete in the 2022 Maccabiah Games. Once a rising star who came of age in the pool during the 1981 Maccabiah Games, Michele now returns in the wake of loss and personal challenges, seeking healing, connection, and a second act. As Michele pushes herself to her physical limits, and revisits past trauma and regrets, she also dives into the larger story of Jewish resilience––discovering that it's never too late to find your light.
To learn more about the film, watch the teaser, or buy tickets, please click the links below.
Website:
https://www.partingthewatersfilm.com/
Teaser:
https://vimeo.com/1104574157?share=copy
Tickets:
https://tickets.showcasecinemas.com/login/0428/192391
"Parting the Waters is an intimate and uplifting film that shares the story of a young American girl who dreamed of swimming in the 1980 Olympics. Forty years later, she gathered her teammates to compete in the 2022 Maccabiah, showing the incredible way sports builds Jewish pride and brings us together across time, distance, and loss."
– Don Kent, First Vice President of Maccabi USA
Connect with us!
Maccabi USA
1511 Walnut Street, Suite 401 Philadelphia, PA 19102
email_preview:

headlines: ["Instructions to complete Blue Shield special enrollment application", "Request to resume and submit in-progress Blue Shield application"]
topics: ["Blue Shield of California health plan enrollment"]
anchors: ["account registration", "new application", "confirmation number BSC", "continue application", "notification within 8-10 business days", "shopping portal", "online application", "qualifying life event", "resume application", "special enrollment"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: David Cabrera
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-08-22T23:36:01+00:00
Subject: Special Enrollment Plan Information from Blue Shield of California
Dear Gabriel,
Thank you for your interest in a Blue Shield of California health plan.
The plan options and rates we discussed are listed above.
Now accepting applications for special enrollment*
To be eligible for coverage during special enrollment, you must apply within 60 days (unless otherwise noted) of your qualifying event. Otherwise, you’ll have to wait until the next open enrollment period to apply.
How to view additional plans, get a quote, and apply:
Click Here
Applying is easy:
Click the link above.
Enter your ZIP code, County and Coverage Type.
Click "Subscriber Only" to enter your date of birth.  If you are applying with other family members, click "Family" or " Child" based on who is applying with you and enter their date of birth.
Click the "Let's find your plan" button.
You will see all Plans available in your zip code.
Click "Select Plan" for the plan you want to apply for and then click "Enroll in selected Plan" at the bottom of the page.
If you selected Medical Coverage, you will be asked if you want to add a Dental/Vision Plan.
Click "Next" at the bottom of the page to start the application.  You will be asked to create an account or log into an existing account.
Helpful hints
Do not use any punctuation or special characters when entering your username.
When registering for an account, your password must be at least eight characters long, include a capital letter, a numeral and a special character.  Also, it cannot be the same as your username.
Have your credit card (Visa, Mastercard or Discover) or bank account information ready to make your first payment.
When completing the "terms and conditions" section at the end, make sure you read and scroll down through all the information in the link to be able to click the boxes that say" I agree."
You should receive notification within 8-10 business days, but processing times may take longer.
Since we are out of Open Enrollment and now in a Special Enrollment Period, you must have a Qualifying Life Event (QLE) to apply for coverage.  You will be asked to identify this event and supply supporting documents during the application process.
Feel free to reply to this email if you have any questions.
Sincerely,
David Cabrera
Enrollment Representative
Individual and Family Plans
CA Lic 0E03770
Blue Shield of California
(341) 220-2053 direct
https://www.blueshieldca.com/davidcabrera
*Open enrollment is closed. You may be eligible to enroll due to certain qualifying events that involve a change in family status such as marriage, birth of a child, or loss of health insurance coverage, to name a few.
Blue Shield of California complies with applicable state laws and federal civil rights laws, and does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, ancestry, religion, sex, marital status, gender, gender identity, sexual orientation, age, or disability.
Blue Shield of California cumple con las leyes estatales y las leyes federales de derechos civiles vigentes, y no discrimina por motivos de raza, color, país de origen, ascendencia, religión, sexo, estado civil, género, identidad de género, orientación sexual, edad ni discapacidad.
Blue Shield of California 遵循適用的州法律和聯邦公民權利法律，並且不以種族、膚色、原國籍、血統、宗教、性別、婚姻 狀況、性別認同、性取向、年齡或殘障為由而進行歧視。

Subject: Fwd: 87 Years Since Kristallnacht – Survivors of the Pogrom Warn:  It Can Happen Again
Enviado desde mi iPhone
Inicio del mensaje reenviado:
> **De:** March of the Living
> **Fecha:** 9 de noviembre de 2025, 2:52:45 p. m. ART
> **Para:** raul.kreiman@gmail.com
> **Asunto:** **87 Years Since Kristallnacht – Survivors of the Pogrom Warn:   It Can Happen Again**
> **Responder-Para:** March of the Living
>
>
>   87 Years Since Kristallnacht – Survivors of the Pogrom Warn: It Can Happen Again
> ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏    ͏                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             
>
> | | | | | | | [View this email in your browser]
> ---
> [|
> ---]
> | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | **87 Years Since Kristallnacht – Survivors of the Pogrom Warn:****It Can Happen Again**
> ---
> [|
> ---]
> | |
> #### Walter Bingham (101), George Shefi (94), and Paul Alexander (90) (Photo: Sam Churchill)
> ---
> | | Eighty-seven years ago, on November 9–10, 1938, the **Kristallnacht Pogrom** marked a turning point in history. Across Germany and Austria, Nazi-led mobs burned and looted more than 1,400 synagogues and thousands of Jewish-owned businesses, murdered scores of Jews, and sent some 30,000 to concentration camps. The shattered glass that covered the streets became a warning of what was to follow — the murder of six million Jews and the destruction of centuries of Jewish life across Europe.
> Today, the same forces of **hatred and extremism** are once again on the rise. According to the ADL, nearly half of adults worldwide — over two billion people — hold antisemitic views. In 2023 alone, antisemitic incidents in the U.S. rose by 140%, while attacks on Jews and Jewish institutions spiked globally after Hamas’s October 7, 2023 massacre in Israel. From Manchester to Washington, D.C., Jews are once again being targeted simply for being Jewish.
> Attacks against Jews and Jewish targets have dramatically spiked around the world following the 2023 Hamas attack on Israel. Most recently, two people were murdered during a terrorist attack on a Manchester synagogue in England on Yom Kippur, the holiest day on the Jewish calendar. Just a few months prior to that, two young Israeli embassy staffers were murdered by a terrorist gunman in Washington, D.C. Other attacks on Jewish and Israeli institutions have occurred recently in Canada, Australia, France, Germany, Denmark, and Poland.
> **Holocaust survivors** who witnessed Kristallnacht and have marched with the International March of the Living express deep alarm at these trends, warning that the atmosphere today echoes the darkest days of their youth. **Walter Bingham** (101), **George Shefi** (94), and **Paul Alexander** (90) were all children in Germany during Kristallnacht. Their message today is clear: the world has learned nothing. We must act now — through education, remembrance, and moral courage — to confront antisemitism and all forms of hatred before history repeats itself.
> ---
> | [READ THEIR MESSAGE]
> ---
> | | Two years ago, they retraced their childhood escape from Nazi Germany. The journey, initiated by the International March of the Living, took place just one day after the October 7 attacks. From Germany, they watched as Israel’s southern communities burned during the pogrom that struck the country. They later joined the March of the Living in Poland. Their journey was documented in a short film:
> ---
> [|
> ---]
> | [WATCH NOW]
> ---
> | [READ MORE IN THE WASHINGTON POST]
> ---
> | | | | | | | | | | | | _**"Kristallnacht sought to erase Jewish existence from public life. Eighty-seven years later, the greatest act of defiance is to live openly and proudly as Jews; to educate, to create, to build, and to stand together. Jewish pride is not a slogan; it is the quiet, steadfast continuation of everything our enemies sought to destroy.**_
> _**On this 87th anniversary of Kristallnacht, we remember the shattered glass, but we also remember what was never broken: the Jewish spirit. From the ruins of synagogues rose new communities; from the ashes of hate emerged generations who refused to disappear.”**_
> ---
> | |
>  Scott Saunders, CEO, International March of the Living
> ---
> | | | | | | | | | | | | **Remembering Eve Kugler, BEM (1931-2025)**
> ---
> [|
> ---]
> | |
> #### Eve Kugler z"l, Halle – Germany 2019 (Photo: Sam Churchill)
> ---
> | | Born in 1931 in Halle, Germany, Eve Kugler experienced the horrors of Kristallnacht first hand, before fleeing to France on the eve of World War II.  In 1942, Eve received a visa to the US where she lived for the duration of war. As an adult, Eve worked as a journalist in the US before moving to London in 1990.Through her educational efforts in the UK and beyond, including her participation for over a decade in the March of the Living, Eve educated thousands of young people about the history and lessons of the Holocaust. In 2022 she made a historic visit to Dubai, giving her testimony on Kristallnacht.
> _"Learning what happened to the Jewish people, how terrible it was, and you know, how six million people, including over a million children, perished. That this is something which should not be repeated. And if you understand it and take in what happened, hopefully, that you will do what you can in whatever small way even if it’s just speaking to other people, and telling them about what you’ve seen, and telling them, sharing even just this experience to try and make people see that they should... stop killing each other.”_
>  Eve passed away on April 23, 2025, just a day before she was scheduled to join a delegation of 80 Holocaust survivors on the March of the Living.
> **Watch Eve Kugler’s emotional return to her birthplace in Halle, Germany, together with the UK March of the Living.**[**Jews Forbidden! - Eve Kugler Remembers The 1938 Kristallnacht Pogrom**]
> ---
> [|
> ---]
> | [WATCH NOW]
> ---
> | [READ MORE FROM SCOTT SAUNDERS]
> ---
> | | | | | | | | | | | | **Standing Jewish, Standing Proud: Eighty-Seven Years After Kristallnacht**
> ---
> | | **Molly Phillips, 2025 Participant at the UK March of the Living delegation**
>  “I wish I could write about an upward path of 87 years of diminishing antisemitism. But reality is painfully different. We are seeing Jews murdered in Manchester and Amsterdam, banned from football stadiums, and even arrested for wearing a Magen David. Most disturbingly, I hear our youth - students - calling for renewed violence on university campuses.
> It feels like my duty and my privilege to uphold Jewish life wherever I can. I find strength in the stories of our community, in our collective resilience, and in our shared will to survive. This spirit was solidified for me on March of the Living last spring. Listening to Holocaust survivors, hearing their stories of endurance and renewal, reminded me that Jewish survival is not only about living through tragedy; it is about choosing life after it.
> Together, we marched. We did not stroll or wander; we marched – a statement of righteous survival and defiant continuity.
> Looking ahead, I see love stronger than hate, kindness over cruelty, spirit over destruction. Peace may feel distant, but it is not out of reach - and a strong, proud Jewish community will help lead us there”.
> ---
> | [READ MOLLY’S OP-ED]
> ---
> | | | | | | | | | | | |

headlines: ["Early voting window communicated for Newton municipal election", "John Chaimanis announces endorsement by Newton Firefighters Association Local 863", "John Chaimanis requests feedback and support for Newton City Council campaign"]
anchors: ["Early Voting Days and Hours", "Class 1 by ISO", "Early VOTING", "answer the questions", "vote early", "MA communities", "lawn sign", "New Endorsement", "fire protection", "mail in Ballot", "Election Day", "Newton City Hall", "volunteer"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: John Chaimanis
To: GABRIEL
Time: 2025-10-27T19:39:09+00:00
Subject: Tell Me What Matters to You
Endorsed by: Marc Laredo, Lenny Gentile, John Oliver, Tarik
Lucas, Pam Wright, Julia Malakie, Randy Block, Rena Getz, Alan
Lobovits, Stephen Farrell, Paul Levy, Chris Markiewicz, Paul
Coletti, David Micley, Margaret Albright
Hello Neighbor!
I've been all over town knocking on doors listening to your
concerns, and if we've not yet met, I want to hear from you!
I strive to be a leader who listens. The City Council REPRESENTS
the will of the people, and Newton is asking for reasonable
leaders that want the best for everyone, listening to all sides
and taking action that represents fair compromise.
So tell me,
**********************
"What matters to you?"
What are your hopes for Newton?
How do you feel we can make Newton the best it can be?
What is the biggest issue facing Newton today and how we can
practically address it?
And a fun one: What type of retail do you want to see in Newton?
-->Answer the questions 
Answer the questions ( https://johnchaimanis.org/feedback )
What will you get from me as your next at large councilor?
An independent thinker. A person who asks questions. A person who
is fully human (mistakes and all).
I’ve lived my life fighting for social justice in education,
poverty and for the environment, not telling people that they
should be doing something, but just doing what I could to make a
positive impact - listening to stakeholders and finding solutions
to move the ball forward for the common good.
An independent thinker questions all sides - preconceived
notions, assumptions and motives. For people who have made the
effort to get to know me, they know that I deeply care for
humanity and I’m always open to hearing feedback.
If you feel that my life of service, my entrepreneurial
experiences of making positive change in the world, my background
in finance, and my approach of listening to all sides resonates
with you, then I humbly ask for your vote.
My Top Priorities
Here's what I stand for:
Fiscal Responsibility: Nearly every decision that the City
Council votes on has financial implications. As an experienced
financial executive, I will be a voice for reason working to
strengthen Newton’s finances, while living within our means.
Funding our schools properly is an investment in our present and
our future.
Representing Local Voices on Development Matters: My job is to
ensure representation, and I will work to ensure resident's
voices are heard when changes are planned. I will work for
increased transparency between the planning department and the
city council.
Local Economy & Sustainability: As a small business owner, I am
focused on enabling business to establish and grow through
streamlined permitting, providing support structures, and in
attracting shared work spaces – both commercial and in the arts.
As a clean energy professional I will work to advance our Climate
Action Plan in ways that save money and green our planet.
Read more about me and my policy platform at
johnchaimanis.org/policy .
New Endorsement
I am pleased to share that I have received the endorsement of
Newton Firefighters Association, Local 863. These brave first
responders are heroes who work tirelessly behind the scenes
responding to the moments in life when no one else can. The
Newton Fire Department is rated Class 1 by ISO, the highest for
fire protection, an elite rating that has been earned by only a
select group of MA communities.
ENDORSEMENTS: Marc Laredo, Lenny Gentile, John Oliver, Tarik
Lucas, Pam Wright, Julia Malakie, Randy Block, Rena Getz, Alan
Lobovits, Stephen Farrell, Paul Levy, Chris Markiewicz, Paul
Coletti, David Micley, Margaret Albright
Early VOTING at City Hall has STARTED
All registered voters can vote early starting from Saturday
October 25th to Wednesday October 29th at Newton City Hall. Make
a plan to vote early or on Election Day, November 4th!
Early Voting Days and Hours
Saturday October 25, 2025 11 am-5pm
Sunday October 26, 2025 11 am-5pm
Monday October 27, 2025 8:30 am-8pm
Tuesday October 28, 2025 8:30 am-5pm
Wednesday October 29 8:30 am-5pm
Newton City Hall
1000 Commonwealth Ave, Newton Centre, MA 02459
Take Action
1) VOTE now (if you have a mail in Ballot), or MAKE A PLAN to
vote in person between Oct 25th - Nov 5th.
2) Talk to your friends about our campaign. Forward on this email
and share the website.
3) Donate, request a lawn sign, or volunteer by emailing
chaimanisatlarge@gmail.com
Thank you,
John
johnchaimanis.org 
chaimanisatlarge@gmail.com

Perdoname pero quise consultarte a vos, just in case.
Me soluciono un par de cosas.

Probe con el y luego con la Mama. Todo OK.
Probare maniana con la Mama con el sistema de la Facu a ver si funciona gambier sin problem as.
2. Me conecto la Dell a la impresora, de modo  que pueda usarla con la Dell o con la Vaio.
3. Haste ahora no tenia el Office habilitado en la Dell. Para hacerlo tenia que pagan unos 28 gr/yr con la credit card.
No sabia que Lau tiene un sistema trucho.
Me instalo un sistema trucho pero mas moderno que el que tiene Lau,o sea intermedio.
No se si me olvido algo.
Extensores. Recomendo una marca. 3 extensores. El los ubica para tender internet en todo el dto.
Con eso install do, le volvemos a pedir a la empresa que nos provee internet/TV/Telefonia Fija. Que nos install Fibra optica.
Con eso se logia internet de calidad superior.
That’s all, folks.
Gracias por tu patiencia y tolerancia
Creo que si uno escribe en Spanish con este iPad, la posibilidad de que cambie letras/palabras es Alta.
Como te fue en California con Memorious?
Abrazos

Hi.
Shmully Hecht here in New Haven. I pray your summer is going well and apologize for a blind email. I am looking for you and a few others... Soulfest.
We are planning a Shabtai Boston event on Sept 10th and have you residing in the area. We would like to invite you via a paperless post invitation. Kindly confirm or deny same as it would help us with our records and invitations. If you are not in the Boston area, kindly advise on your current residence, allowing us to better curate our invitation lists geographically.
Many thanks and looking forward to hearing from you about this and all pertinent matters in these turbulent times.
Peace and love,
Shmully Hecht

Mariela Zirlinger

The invitation is very kind and the place looks glamorous! I would love to go, but it won't be possible to cross the pond then.

Mariela.

Dear Mariela,
I hope you had a good summer and all is good with work and family.
I am writing to renew the invite to our Anniversary party on October 19th in Trieste (Italy). We would be delighted to have you all.
The programme is the following: 11.30 am celebration of the Mass in Sanctuary of Monrupino (The Sanctuary of Monrupino), then we will move to Castello Formentini (Home - Castello Formentini), for the lunch and dancing until 1 am
I hope you can make it.
Daniela and Paolo

Daniela

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Terrace Apartments 
Date: Mon, Jul 14, 2025 at 1:38 PM
Subject: Re: Inquiry about car
To: Walnut 203 James Bowden, Tobias (Toby) Kreiman, Catherine Glossop 
Hi Toby,
The same parking space is available for $75/month.  We are not set up for
EV charging, but we do have a GFCI 110V outlet in front of the parking
space that can be used to charge a vehicle.  If you plan to use this outlet
for charging, we will need to charge you for your electrical use.
Regards,
Franklin

potentially getting a car in the coming months.
1. Is a parking spot still available and would this still be $75 per month?

already in the garage? If not, is there any interest from the building in
installing one?
Thanks for the help.
Best,
Toby

full_content:
Message 1
From: Mariela Zirlinger
To: gkreiman@gmail.com
Time: 2025-03-28T20:10:20+00:00
Subject: Fwd: CIEE Billing Statement
A vos también te llegó esto?
Sent from my iPhone
Begin forwarded message:
From: CIEE Study Billing Team 
Date: March 28, 2025 at 4:03:24 PM EDT
To: Betina Kreiman 
Cc: mzirlinger@hotmail.com
Subject: CIEE Billing Statement
Dear Student:
Congratulations on your acceptance to a CIEE program! The billing statement for your CIEE Study Program is attached to this message. FOR STUDENTS STUDYING IN MULTIPLE CIEE LOCATIONS, you will receive an updated billing statement reflecting all program fees for all locations within 7 business days. Also attached is payment remittance information.
A copy of this billing statement can also be viewed in your CIEE online account. To view the statement there:
Log onto your CIEE My Account and open your current program application.  Scroll down the page and you will see billing statements listed by date under the header titled FINANCIAL INFORMATION.
Please note that you may be billed for some components of your study abroad program by your home college or university, but you are responsible for paying CIEE for all fees shown on your CIEE billing statement.  Please contact the study abroad office at your home college/university for information on any fees they may charge for your program.
If you are interested in CIEE’s Standard Payment Plan and/or Financial Aid Deferral please download forms here; Financial Aid Deferral or Student Payment Plan. Please note students who are autonomous are not eligible for either the Standard Payment Plan or the Financial Aid Deferral.
  *   A Standard Payment Plan will break your total program payment into 3 installments.
  *   1st payment - 50% plus the $50 standard payment plan fee
  *   2nd payment 25%
  *   3rd and final payment 25%
  *   A Financial Aid Deferral allows you to defer your payment for the amount that you will be receiving in financial aid. Types of aid that can be deferred include Student, Parent, or Private Alternative Loans, Scholarships, and Grants.
If you have any questions regarding your CIEE bill, please contact studybillingteam@ciee.org.
Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.
CIEE Study Billing Team

headlines: ["Hotel sends welcome and information for upcoming Hyatt Regency Orange County stay", "I forward Hyatt Regency Orange County welcome email to personal account"]
anchors: ["hotel activities", "Disneyland tickets", "on-site dining", "forward welcome email", "Hyatt mobile app", "Disneyland shuttle tickets", "dining options", "parking per night", "arrivals prior to 4:00 PM", "Hyatt information links"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: ALICA-Shared MB-Front Office Managers
To:
  -
Time: 2025-05-27T23:24:48+00:00
Subject: Welcome to the Hyatt Regency Orange County
Greetings from the Hyatt Regency Orange County,
We are thrilled to welcome you to our property, and excited to share everything we have to offer during your stay with us!
Here's what you need to know...
  *   ARRIVALS PRIOR TO 4:00 PM:  Stop by the Front Desk and we are happy to get your reservation queued if your room is not yet ready in addition to allowing you access to our amenities. Just leave your luggage with us and once the room is ready, we will send you a text notification.
  *   DISNEYLAND:  Click HERE to purchase your Disneyland tickets, and discover the magic that awaits you! Skip the hassle of parking, and ride with us! Shuttle tickets may be purchased HERE for only $6.00 per person.
     *   Want our recommended tips and tricks for the parks? Click HERE for the insider scoop on Disney's do's and don'ts!
  *   PARKING:  Our Self-Parking Lot is located directly behind the hotel, off of Chapman Avenue, available for $30.00 per night. Our Valet service is conveniently located on our Front Drive, available for $38.00 per night.
  *   ON-SITE DINING:  From breakfast to satisfying your sweet-tooth, we have got you covered! Click HERE to see our five dining options, as well as their hours of operation!
  *   ACTIVITIES:  Whether you are seeking excitement or looking to relax and roast some s'mores by the fire pit: there is something for everyone to enjoy. Check out our Recreation Deck for activities like pickleball, basketball, shuffleboard, ping pong, and much more!  For a more relaxing experience, head to our North Tower Pool, featuring a peaceful atmosphere along with a hot tub, perfect for unwinding and rejuvenating after a day of fun.
Have any questions or a request?  Text us at (714) 294-2178.
To ensure a prompt response, please do not reply to this email.
Download our  Mobile App to access your digital room key and unlock exclusive membership benefits.
We look forward to welcoming you soon!
Your Guest Experience Team
HYATT REGENCY ORANGE COUNTY
11999 Harbor Boulevard, Garden Grove, CA 92840, USA
T 714-750-1234
orangecounty.regency.hyatt.com

full_content:
Message 1

To:
  - Mariela Zirlinger
  - betinakreiman@gmail.com

Time: 2025-10-30T15:29:16+00:00
Subject: Harvard Student Health Insurance-- ACTION NEEDED AROUND X-Mas!
@ Betina, vas a tener que enrol en Harvard Student Health plan para el Spring term.
Papi no a tener mas el insurance de Harvard y la mia sale mas cara y es mas chota. Vas a seguir teniendo buena insurance por medio de Harvard con Blue Cross Blue Shield, asi que va a ser facil que continues con los mismos medicos, etc.
Hay que hacer un tramite en diciembre - acordemonos durante el Winter Break!!
This is the info I gathered:
HOW TO CHANGE OR CANCEL COVERAGE You cannot make changes to your coverage outside of the Open Enrollment Period unless you experience  a life-changing event. Enrollment Due to Life-Changing Events Typically, you may add coverage for you or a dependent within 45 days of a life-changing event, which may include • entry into the country, • loss of other health insurance coverage, • marriage, • birth of a child, legal adoption, or legal guardianship. The coverage and cost are prorated to the date of the life-changing event. To make a change to your coverage outside of the Open Enrollment Period, you must submit documentation to Member Services at 617-495-2008 or mservices@huhs.harvard.edu.
• All Harvard students are automatically enrolled in HUSHP and pay the  Student Health Fee (SHF). • The Student Health Insurance Plan (SHIP) provides a critical safety  net to ensure that all students, regardless of location, have access  to quality and affordable health care. • Charges are applied to student accounts and will show up as two separate line items: one for SHF and one for SHIP.
HOW TO RE-ENROLL IF YOU’VE WAIVED COVERAGE Students who previously waived coverage from the Student Health Insurance Plan (SHIP) and/or the Student Health Fee (SHF) may be eligible to re-enroll in one or both parts of Harvard University Student Health Program (HUSHP) under certain conditions. Criteria for rescinding waivers 1. Loss of alternative insurance no more than 60 days ago: The student must submit a waiver-rescind application to Member Services, along with official documentation of the loss of coverage. Documentation must show the student’s name and exact termination date. The cost of SHIP will be prorated to the first day of the effective date of coverage. 2. Loss of alternative insurance 61 or more days ago: The student must submit a waiver-rescind application to Member Services, along with official documentation of the loss of coverage. Documentation must show the student’s name and exact termination date. The cost of SHIP will be prorated to the first day of the effective date of coverage. The student will be assessed a penalty fee of $150 for each calendar month beyond the allowed 60 days. Coverage can be reinstated up to 102 days from the date that HUSHP Member Services receives a completed application or the beginning of the term of coverage, whichever is sooner. 3. Without a loss of insurance before the waiver deadline: The student must submit a waiver-rescind application to Member Services. The student will be enrolled effective on the start date of the term they are applying to rescind. The student will be charged a $50 processing fee. The cost of the plan is not prorated. 4. Without a loss of insurance after the waiver deadline: The student will not be allowed to enroll in SHIP until the following coverage term. Learn more about re-enrolling in the HUSHP after you’ve waived coverage.
Harvard University Student Health  Program Member Services For questions about your benefits and plan details Visit: hushp.harvard.edu
 Call: 617-495-2008 Email: mservices@huhs.harvard.edu
HOW TO CHANGE OR CANCEL COVERAGE You cannot make changes to your coverage outside of the Open Enrollment Period unless you experience  a life-changing event. Enrollment Due to Life-Changing Events Typically, you may add coverage for you or a dependent within 45 days of a life-changing event, which may include • entry into the country, • loss of other health insurance coverage, • marriage, • birth of a child, legal adoption, or legal guardianship. The coverage and cost are prorated to the date of the life-changing event. To make a change to your coverage outside of the Open Enrollment Period, you must submit documentation to Member Services at 617-495-2008 or _[mservices@huhs.harvard.edu]_.
HOW TO RE-ENROLL IF YOU’VE WAIVED COVERAGE Students who previously waived coverage from the Student Health Insurance Plan (SHIP) and/or the Student Health Fee (SHF) may be eligible to re-enroll in one or both parts of Harvard University Student Health Program (HUSHP) under certain conditions. Criteria for rescinding waivers 1. Loss of alternative insurance no more than 60 days ago: The student must submit a waiver-rescind application to Member Services, along with official documentation of the loss of coverage. Documentation must show the student’s name and exact termination date. The cost of SHIP will be prorated to the first day of the effective date of coverage. 2. Loss of alternative insurance 61 or more days ago: The student must submit a waiver-rescind application to Member Services, along with official documentation of the loss of coverage. Documentation must show the student’s name and exact termination date. The cost of SHIP will be prorated to the first day of the effective date of coverage. The student will be assessed a penalty fee of $150 for each calendar month beyond the allowed 60 days. Coverage can be reinstated up to 102 days from the date that HUSHP Member Services receives a completed application or the beginning of the term of coverage, whichever is sooner. 3\. Without a loss of insurance before the waiver deadline: The student must submit a waiver-rescind application to Member Services. The student will be enrolled effective on the start date of the term they are applying to rescind. The student will be charged a $50 processing fee. The cost of the plan is not prorated. 4. Without a loss of insurance after the waiver deadline: The student will not be allowed to enroll in SHIP until the following coverage term. Learn more about re-enrolling in the HUSHP after you’ve waived coverage.

headlines: ["Dinner invitation for Rocco at my home", "Dinner with Rocco scheduled for June 27 in Newton", "Plan to meet in Boston while Rocco is in Cambridge", "Rocco accepts dinner invitation", "Rocco arrives in Boston and requests to meet", "Rocco reconfirms attendance at June 27 dinner", "Rocco secures AstroAI internship in Cambridge"]
topics: ["Dinner with Rocco", "AstroAI pasant\u00eda on interpretability and multi-modal models", "Meeting with Rocco in Cambridge"]
anchors: ["interpretability", "acepta la invitaci\u00f3n", "Cambridge stay", "Visual Search Review", "6:30pm", "reconfirms attendance", "disponible estos d\u00edas", "datos de Astronom\u00eda", "venir a cenar a casa", "alrededor de las 6:30pm", "arrange to meet", "modelos multi-modales", "llegu\u00e9 a Boston", "ah\u00ed nos vemos", "Perfecto", "Perfecto si", "pasant\u00eda en AstroAI", "viernes de la semana que viene", "let me know when you are in Boston", "ya estoy instalado", "otros amigos quizas", "190 Temple St", "confirmar cena", "Viernes 27/junio"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Rocco Di Tella
To: Gabriel Kreiman
Time: 2025-05-09T13:00:00-03:00
Subject: Café en Cambridge entre Junio y Agosto?
Hola Gabriel!
Cómo estás?
Te quería contar que quedé en una pasantía en AstroAI
 en Harvard, y voy a estar Junio, Julio y
Agosto en Cambridge. El proyecto es sobre interpretabilidad y modelos
multi-modales aplicados a datos de Astronomía. Es una oportunidad buenísima
para mí y estoy muy contento. Cada vez más estoy definiendo que el tema que
más me interesa para un doctorado es interpretabilidad de modelos.
También vi una notificación en el Overleaf del Visual Search Review esta
semana. Francamente, leí y aprendí muchísimo sobre el tema y armé notas
personales bastante extensas estos últimos meses. Pero me costó escribir.
Mientras pasaba el tiempo y resumía más papers, me ponía perfeccionista y
más me costaba escribir. Particularmente, creo que debería haber pedido
ayuda más seguido.
Más allá de esa pequeña reflexión y mea culpa, quería aprovechar que *voy a
estar en Cambridge estos meses: me encantaría si logramos encontrar un
momento para tomar un café*. Estoy muy entusiasmado de aplicar a programas
para el año que viene. Aprendí muchísimo durante la tesis y también
trabajando en investigación después de eso. Quiero pedirte algunos consejos
sobre empezar una carrera académica, pero más que nada hablar un rato.
Sé que en el verano la gente viaja, pero por si coincidimos, voy a estar
entre el 2 de Junio y el 11 de agosto en Cambridge.
Un abrazo,
Rocco
Hola Gabriel!
Cómo estás?
Te quería contar que quedé en una pasantía en [AstroAI](https://astroai.cfa.harvard.edu/) en Harvard, y voy a estar Junio, Julio y Agosto en Cambridge. El proyecto es sobre interpretabilidad y modelos multi-modales aplicados a datos de Astronomía. Es una oportunidad buenísima para mí y estoy muy contento. Cada vez más estoy definiendo que el tema que más me interesa para un doctorado es interpretabilidad de modelos.

Message 1
From: Joe
To: Gabriel Kreiman
Time: 2025-10-09T18:00:30-04:00
Subject: CGMS Recommendation
Hi Gabriel,
Hope all is well. I'm curious what your decision was with the startup. I
have two part-time jobs going on now, one through Meta and the other
through a retail website.
I decided to apply for a Montessori Teaching Certificate (making this
decision a little last minute). I am applying through this program to be
certified for Elementary ages 6-12 (https://www.cgms.edu/elementary/). The
deadline is Monday the 13th. Would you mind please filling out this
recommendation form and sending it to admissions@cgms.edu before then? It
looks like a simple questionnaire with mostly ranking me on a scale of 1-5.
I understand if it is too last minute.
Let's catch up soon.
Warmly,
Joe

headlines: ["Confirmation of participation in Fourth of July Renaissance Weekend in Monterey", "Forwarding Renaissance Weekend registration confirmation to family members", "Forwarding Renaissance Weekend registration confirmation to personal email"]
topics: ["Fourth of July Renaissance Weekend in Monterey"]
anchors: ["forwarded message", "Renaissance Weekend", "Monterey", "personal email", "attached document", "image attachment", "program assignments", "Fourth of July Renaissance Weekend", "registration confirmation", "registration fees waived"]
full_content:
Message 1
From: Renaissance Weekend
To:
  - 'gabriel.kreiman@tch.harvard.edu'
  - 'W:'
  - 'SG W:'
Time: 2025-06-24T16:34:02+00:00
Subject: Labor Day Renaissance Weekend - Registration Confirmation
We look forward to welcoming you to the Fourth of July Renaissance Weekend in Monterey.
Attached is the information we have in our Renaissance Weekend records for you and your family/guest(s).  Please check to be sure it is accurate.  If you have any corrections or comments, kindly send them to us in the body of an e-mail to info@renwkd.org (rather than within the attached document).  Please note:  we do not need phone numbers.
Since the gathering's program consists of presentations by all participants and therefore is not organized until about one month before the Weekend, we'll be proposing your lecture, seminar, and/or panel assignments at that time.  Little, if any preparation, will be necessary, as the sessions are curated to prompt participant's customary presentations and will focus on your specific expertise.  And the sessions are all highly informal and off-the-record.
As our invitation letter noted, we would be pleased to waive Registration Fees and provide one room & Common Meals for you and your accompanying family (sons & daughters ages 21 or younger) from the first evening program through the final morning session.  Transportation would be your responsibility.
The Tentative Program and Program Assignments will be sent to you by e-mail approximately two weeks prior to the start of the Weekend.
If you have any questions, feel free to let us know.  Your participation will certainly help ensure that this will be yet another memorable Renaissance Weekend.
With thanks and regards,
Renaissance Weekend
info@renwkd.org | www.RenaissanceWeekend.org
Post Office Box 22049, Charleston, 
SC 29413
